II 
Calendar No. 4 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  S. 6 
To amend title 18, United States Code, to prohibit a health care practitioner 
from failing to exercise the proper degree of care in the case of a child who survives an abortion or attempted abortion. 
IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES 
JANUARY 15, 2025 
Mr. L ANKFORD (for himself, Mr. B ANKS , Mr. T HUNE , Mrs. H YDE-SMITH , Mr. 
RISCH, Ms. L UMMIS , Mrs. B RITT, Mr. M CCONNELL , Mr. W ICKER , Mrs. 
BLACKBURN , Mr. C RAPO , Mrs. F ISCHER , Mr. G RASSLEY , Mr. H OEVEN , 
Mr. M ARSHALL , Mr. T ILLIS , Mr. B UDD, Mr. S COTT of South Carolina, 
Mr. J OHNSON , Mr. S HEEHY , Mr. T UBERVILLE , Mr. H AGERTY , Mr. C UR-
TIS, Mr. Y OUNG , Mr. R ICKETTS , Mr. C RAMER , Mr. B ARRASSO , Mr. K EN-
NEDY , Mr. C ORNYN , Mr. C ASSIDY , Mr. R OUNDS , Ms. E RNST , Mr. S COTT  
of Florida, Mr. D AINES , Mr. M ULLIN , Mr. G RAHAM , Mr. C RUZ, Mr. 
SCHMITT , Mr. L EE, Mr. S ULLIVAN , Mr. M ORAN , Mr. C OTTON , Mr. 
HAWLEY , Mr. M CCORMICK , and Mr. B OOZMAN ) introduced the following 
bill; which was read the first time 
JANUARY 16, 2025 
Read the second time and placed on the calendar 
A BILL 
To amend title 18, United States Code, to prohibit a health 
care practitioner from failing to exercise the proper de-gree of care in the case of a child who survives an abortion or attempted abortion. 
VerDate Sep 11 2014 01:02 Jan 17, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6652 E:\BILLS\S6.PCS S6kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
2 
•S 6 PCSBe it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Born-Alive Abortion 4
Survivors Protection Act’’. 5
SEC. 2. FINDINGS. 6
Congress finds the following: 7
(1) If an abortion results in the live birth of an 8
infant, the infant is a legal person for all purposes 9
under the laws of the United States, and entitled to 10
all the protections of such laws. 11
(2) Any infant born alive after an abortion or 12
within a hospital, clinic, or other facility has the 13
same claim to the protection of the law that would 14
arise for any newborn, or for any person who comes 15
to a hospital, clinic, or other facility for screening 16
and treatment or otherwise becomes a patient within 17
its care. 18
SEC. 3. BORN-ALIVE INFANTS PROTECTION. 19
(a) R EQUIREMENTS PERTAINING TO BORN-ALIVE 20
ABORTION SURVIVORS .—Chapter 74 of title 18, United 21
States Code, is amended by inserting after section 1531 22
the following: 23
VerDate Sep 11 2014 01:02 Jan 17, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\S6.PCS S6kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
3 
•S 6 PCS‘‘§ 1532. Requirements pertaining to born-alive abor-1
tion survivors 2
‘‘(a) R EQUIREMENTS FOR HEALTH CARE PRACTI - 3
TIONERS .—In the case of an abortion or attempted abor- 4
tion that results in a child born alive: 5
‘‘(1) D EGREE OF CARE REQUIRED ; IMMEDIATE  6
ADMISSION TO A HOSPITAL .—Any health care practi- 7
tioner present at the time the child is born alive 8
shall— 9
‘‘(A) exercise the same degree of profes- 10
sional skill, care, and diligence to preserve the 11
life and health of the child as a reasonably dili- 12
gent and conscientious health care practitioner 13
would render to any other child born alive at 14
the same gestational age; and 15
‘‘(B) following the exercise of skill, care, 16
and diligence required under subparagraph (A), 17
ensure that the child born alive is immediately 18
transported and admitted to a hospital. 19
‘‘(2) M ANDATORY REPORTING OF VIOLA - 20
TIONS .—A health care practitioner or any employee 21
of a hospital, a physician’s office, or an abortion 22
clinic who has knowledge of a failure to comply with 23
the requirements of paragraph (1) shall immediately 24
report the failure to an appropriate State or Federal 25
law enforcement agency, or to both. 26
VerDate Sep 11 2014 01:02 Jan 17, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00003 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\S6.PCS S6kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
4 
•S 6 PCS‘‘(b) P ENALTIES .— 1
‘‘(1) I N GENERAL .—Whoever violates subsection 2
(a) shall be fined under this title, imprisoned for not 3
more than 5 years, or both. 4
‘‘(2) I NTENTIONAL KILLING OF CHILD BORN  5
ALIVE .—Whoever intentionally performs or attempts 6
to perform an overt act that kills a child born alive 7
described under subsection (a), shall be punished as 8
under section 1111 of this title for intentionally kill- 9
ing or attempting to kill a human being. 10
‘‘(c) B AR TO PROSECUTION .—The mother of a child 11
born alive described under subsection (a) may not be pros-12
ecuted for a violation of this section, an attempt to violate 13
this section, a conspiracy to violate this section, or an of-14
fense under section 3 or 4 of this title based on such a 15
violation. 16
‘‘(d) C IVILREMEDIES .— 17
‘‘(1) C IVIL ACTION BY A WOMAN ON WHOM AN  18
ABORTION IS PERFORMED .—If a child is born alive 19
and there is a violation of subsection (a), the woman 20
upon whom the abortion was performed or at- 21
tempted may, in a civil action against any person 22
who committed the violation, obtain appropriate re- 23
lief. 24
VerDate Sep 11 2014 01:02 Jan 17, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00004 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\S6.PCS S6kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
5 
•S 6 PCS‘‘(2) A PPROPRIATE RELIEF .—Appropriate relief 1
in a civil action under this subsection includes— 2
‘‘(A) objectively verifiable money damage 3
for all injuries, psychological and physical, occa- 4
sioned by the violation of subsection (a); 5
‘‘(B) statutory damages equal to 3 times 6
the cost of the abortion or attempted abortion; 7
and 8
‘‘(C) punitive damages. 9
‘‘(3) A TTORNEY ’S FEE FOR PLAINTIFF .—The 10
court shall award a reasonable attorney’s fee to a 11
prevailing plaintiff in a civil action under this sub- 12
section. 13
‘‘(4) A TTORNEY ’S FEE FOR DEFENDANT .—If a 14
defendant in a civil action under this subsection pre- 15
vails and the court finds that the plaintiff’s suit was 16
frivolous, the court shall award a reasonable attor- 17
ney’s fee in favor of the defendant against the plain- 18
tiff. 19
‘‘(e) D EFINITIONS .—In this section the following 20
definitions apply: 21
‘‘(1) A BORTION .—The term ‘abortion’ means 22
the use or prescription of any instrument, medicine, 23
drug, or any other substance or device— 24

of a woman known to be pregnant; or 2
‘‘(B) to intentionally terminate the preg- 3
nancy of a woman known to be pregnant, with 4
an intention other than— 5
‘‘(i) after viability, to produce a live 6
birth and preserve the life and health of 7
the child born alive; or 8
‘‘(ii) to remove a dead unborn child. 9
‘‘(2) A TTEMPT .—The term ‘attempt’, with re- 10
spect to an abortion, means conduct that, under the 11
circumstances as the actor believes them to be, con- 12
stitutes a substantial step in a course of conduct 13
planned to culminate in performing an abortion. 14
‘‘(3) B ORN ALIVE .—The term ‘born alive’ has 15
the meaning given that term in section 8 of title 1, 16
United States Code (commonly known as the ‘Born- 17
Alive Infants Protection Act’).’’. 18
(b) C ONFORMING AMENDMENTS .— 19
(1) The table of sections for chapter 74 of title 20
18, United States Code, is amended by adding at 21
the end the following: 22
‘‘1532. Requirements pertaining to born-alive abortion survivors.’’. 
(2) The chapter heading for chapter 74 of title 23
18, United States Code, is amended by striking 24
VerDate Sep 11 2014 01:02 Jan 17, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00006 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\S6.PCS S6kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
7 
•S 6 PCS‘‘PARTIAL-BIRTH ABORTIONS ’’ and insert- 1
ing ‘‘ABORTIONS ’’. 2
(3) The table of chapters for part I of title 18, 3
United States Code, is amended by striking the item 4
relating to chapter 74 and inserting the following: 5
‘‘74. Abortion ....................................................................................... 1531’’. 
SEC. 4. EFFECTIVE DATE. 6
This Act shall take effect one day after the date of 7
enactment. 8

VerDate Sep 11 2014 01:02 Jan 17, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00008 Fmt 6651 Sfmt 6651 E:\BILLS\S6.PCS S6kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB



H. Res. 53 
In the House of Representatives, U. S., 
January 22, 2025. 
Resolved, That at any time after adoption of this resolu-
tion the Speaker may, pursuant to clause 2(b) of rule XVIII, declare the House resolved into the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union for consideration of the bill (H.R. 471) to expedite under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 and improve forest management activities on National Forest System lands, on public lands under the jurisdiction of the Bureau of Land Management, and on Tribal lands to return resilience to overgrown, fire-prone for-ested lands, and for other purposes. The first reading of the bill shall be dispensed with. All points of order against con-sideration of the bill are waived. General debate shall be con-fined to the bill and shall not exceed one hour equally divided and controlled by the chair and ranking minority member of the Committee on Natural Resources or their respective des-ignees. After general debate the bill shall be considered for amendment under the five-minute rule. The bill shall be con-sidered as read. All points of order against provisions in the 
2 
•HRES 53 EH bill are waived. No amendment to the bill shall be in order 
except those printed in the report of the Committee on Rules accompanying this resolution. Each such amendment may be offered only in the order printed in the report, may be offered only by a Member designated in the report, shall be consid-ered as read, shall be debatable for the time specified in the report equally divided and controlled by the proponent and an opponent, shall not be subject to amendment, and shall not be subject to a demand for division of the question in the House or in the Committee of the Whole. All points of order against such amendments are waived. At the conclusion of consideration of the bill for amendment the Committee shall rise and report the bill to the House with such amendments as may have been adopted. The previous question shall be considered as ordered on the bill and amendments thereto to final passage without intervening motion except one motion to recommit. 
S
EC. 2. Upon adoption of this resolution it shall be in 
order to consider in the House the bill (S. 5) to require the Secretary of Homeland Security to take into custody aliens who have been charged in the United States with theft, and for other purposes. All points of order against consideration of the bill are waived. The bill shall be considered as read. All points of order against provisions in the bill are waived. The previous question shall be considered as ordered on the 
3 
•HRES 53 EH bill and on any amendment thereto to final passage without 
intervening motion except: (1) one hour of debate equally di-vided and controlled by the chair and ranking minority mem-ber of the Committee on the Judiciary or their respective des-ignees; and (2) one motion to commit. 
Attest: 
Clerk.

1STSESSION  H. R. 186 
IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES 
JANUARY 22, 2025 
Received; read twice and referred to the Committee on Energy and Natural 
Resources 
AN ACT 
To authorize the National Medal of Honor Museum Founda-
tion to establish a commemorative work on the National Mall to honor the extraordinary acts of valor, selfless service, and sacrifice displayed by Medal of Honor recipi-ents. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:22 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H186.RFS H186ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
2 
HR 186 RFSSECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 1
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Hershel ‘Woody’ Wil- 2
liams National Medal of Honor Monument Location Act’’. 3
SEC. 2. FINDINGS. 4
Congress finds the following: 5
(1) Congress in 2021 unanimously passed, and 6
the President signed, Public Law 117–80 (40 U.S.C. 7
8903 note), which authorized the National Medal of 8
Honor Museum Foundation to establish on Federal 9
land in the District of Columbia a commemorative 10
work to honor the acts of valor, selfless service, and 11
sacrifice displayed by Medal of Honor recipients. 12
(2) The Medal of Honor was established by 13
President Abraham Lincoln and first awarded 160 14
years ago on March 25, 1863, and is part of Lin- 15
coln’s lasting and living legacy. 16
(3) In 1991, during the administration of Presi- 17
dent George H.W. Bush, this legacy was extended 18
further when National Medal of Honor Day was es- 19
tablished as March 25th of each year. 20
(4) The Medal of Honor is awarded to all 21
branches of the United States Armed Forces as our 22
nation’s highest recognition for valor in combat. 23
(5) The number of living Medal of Honor re- 24
cipients has been steadily declining, making it even 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:22 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H186.RFS H186ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
3 
HR 186 RFSmore crucial to honor and recognize their heroic sac- 1
rifices and inspire future generations. 2
(6) Hershel ‘‘Woody’’ Williams, the last World 3
War II Medal of Honor recipient, passed away in 4
2022 and laid in honor at the United States Capitol. 5
(7) The Medal of Honor represents the very 6
best of our Nation—ordinary citizens, who took ex- 7
traordinary action above and beyond the call of duty 8
and became heroes of our Republic. 9
(8) These examples inspire all citizens and ig- 10
nite within us the very spirit of America. 11
(9) The Medal of Honor rises to the level of su- 12
preme national and historical importance necessary 13
to warrant representation on the National Mall. 14
(10) Locating the National Medal of Honor 15
Monument in close proximity to the Lincoln Memo- 16
rial within the Reserve would be a respectful exten- 17
sion of his enduring legacy and recognition of what 18
ordinary people can accomplish when working for 19
the greater good. 20
SEC. 3. NATIONAL MEDAL OF HONOR MONUMENT LOCA-21
TION. 22
(a) S ITE.—Notwithstanding section 8908(c) of title 23
40, United States Code, the commemorative work author-24
ized by section 1(a) of Public Law 117–80 (40 U.S.C. 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:22 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00003 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H186.RFS H186ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
4 
HR 186 RFS8903 note) shall be located within the Reserve (as defined 1
in section 8902(a) of title 40, United States Code). 2
(b) A PPLICABILITY OF COMMEMORATIVE WORKS  3
ACT.—Except as provided in subsection (a), chapter 89 4
of title 40, United States Code (commonly known as the 5
‘‘Commemorative Works Act’’), shall apply to the com-6
memorative work. 7
Passed the House of Representatives January 21, 
2025. 
Attest: KEVIN F. MCCUMBER, 
Clerk. 
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:22 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00004 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H186.RFS H186ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS



IIB 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 187 
IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES 
JANUARY 22, 2025 
Received; read twice and referred to the Committee on Energy and Natural 
Resources 
AN ACT 
To provide for the standardization, consolidation, and publi-
cation of data relating to public outdoor recreational use of Federal waterways among Federal land and water management agencies, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H187.RFS H187ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
2 
HR 187 RFSSECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 1
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Modernizing Access 2
to our Public Waters Act of 2025’’ or the ‘‘MAPWaters 3
Act of 2025’’. 4
SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. 5
In this Act: 6
(1) F EDERAL FISHING RESTRICTION .—The 7
term ‘‘Federal fishing restriction’’ means a defined 8
area in which all or certain fishing activities are 9
temporarily or permanently prohibited or restricted 10
by a Federal land or water management agency. 11
(2) F EDERAL LAND OR WATER MANAGEMENT  12
AGENCY .—The term ‘‘Federal land or water man- 13
agement agency’’ means— 14
(A) the Bureau of Reclamation; 15
(B) the National Park Service; 16
(C) the Bureau of Land Management; 17
(D) the United States Fish and Wildlife 18
Service; and 19
(E) the Forest Service. 20
(3) F EDERAL WATERWAY .—The term ‘‘Federal 21
waterway’’ means waters managed by 1 or more of 22
the relevant Secretaries. 23
(4) F EDERAL WATERWAY RESTRICTION .—The 24
term ‘‘Federal waterway restriction’’ means a re- 25
striction on the access or use of a Federal waterway 26
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H187.RFS H187ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
3 
HR 187 RFSapplied under applicable law by 1 or more of the 1
Secretaries. 2
(5) S ECRETARIES .—The term ‘‘Secretaries’’ 3
means— 4
(A) the Secretary of Agriculture, acting 5
through the Chief of the Forest Service; and 6
(B) the Secretary of the Interior. 7
(6) S TATE .—The term ‘‘State’’ means each of 8
the several States, the District of Columbia, and 9
each territory of the United States. 10
SEC. 3. INTERAGENCY DATA STANDARDIZATION. 11
Not later than 30 months after the date of enactment 12
of this Act, the Secretaries, in coordination with the Fed-13
eral Geographic Data Committee established by section 14
753(a) of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 (43 15
U.S.C. 2802(a)), shall jointly develop and adopt inter-16
agency standards to ensure compatibility and interoper-17
ability among applicable Federal databases with respect 18
to the collection and dissemination of geospatial data re-19
lating to public outdoor recreational access of Federal wa-20
terways and Federal fishing restrictions. 21
SEC. 4. DATA CONSOLIDATION AND PUBLICATION. 22
(a) F EDERAL WATERWAY RESTRICTIONS .—Not later 23
than 5 years after the date of enactment of this Act, each 24
of the Secretaries, to the maximum extent practicable, 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00003 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H187.RFS H187ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
4 
HR 187 RFSshall digitize and make publicly available online, as appli-1
cable, geographic information system data that includes, 2
with respect to Federal waterway restrictions— 3
(1) status information with respect to the con- 4
ditions under which Federal waterways are open or 5
closed to entry or watercraft, including watercraft 6
inspection, decontamination requirements, low-ele- 7
vation aircraft, or diving; 8
(2) the dates on which Federal waterways are 9
seasonally closed to entry or watercraft; 10
(3) the areas of Federal waterways with restric- 11
tions on motorized propulsion, horsepower, or fuel 12
type; 13
(4) the areas of Federal waterways with an- 14
choring restrictions, no wake zones, exclusion zones, 15
danger areas, or vessel speed restrictions; 16
(5) Federal waterway restrictions on the direc- 17
tion of travel, including upstream or downstream 18
travel; and 19
(6) the uses, including by watercraft, that are 20
restricted on each area of a Federal waterway, in- 21
cluding the permissibility of— 22
(A) canoes and other paddlecraft; 23
(B) rafts and driftboats; 24
(C) motorboats; 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00004 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H187.RFS H187ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
5 
HR 187 RFS(D) personal watercraft; 1
(E) airboats; 2
(F) amphibious aircraft; 3
(G) hovercraft; 4
(H) oversnow vehicles and other motorized 5
vehicles on frozen bodies of water; 6
(I) oceangoing ships; 7
(J) swimming; and 8
(K) other applicable recreational activities, 9
as determined to be appropriate by the Secre- 10
taries. 11
(b) F EDERAL WATERWAY ACCESS AND NAVIGATION  12
INFORMATION .—Not later than 5 years after the date of 13
enactment of this Act, each of the Secretaries, to the max-14
imum extent practicable, shall digitize and make publicly 15
available online, as applicable, geographic information sys-16
tem data that includes, with respect to Federal waterway 17
access and navigation information— 18
(1)(A) the location of boat ramps, portages, and 19
fishing access sites under the authority of the Fed- 20
eral land or water management agency; and 21
(B) the identification of the dates on which 22
the facilities and sites identified under subpara- 23
graph (A) are open or closed, as applicable; and 24
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00005 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H187.RFS H187ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
6 
HR 187 RFS(2) bathymetric information and depth charts, 1
as feasible. 2
(c) F EDERAL FISHING RESTRICTIONS .—Not later 3
than 5 years after the date of enactment of this Act, each 4
of the Secretaries, to the maximum extent practicable, 5
shall digitize and make publicly available online geo-6
graphic information system data that describes, with re-7
spect to Federal fishing restrictions— 8
(1) the location and geographic boundaries of 9
Federal fishing restrictions on recreational and com- 10
mercial fishing, including— 11
(A) full or partial closures; 12
(B) no-take zones; and 13
(C) Federal fishing restrictions within or 14
surrounding marine protected areas; 15
(2) Federal fishing restrictions on the use of 16
specific types of equipment or bait; and 17
(3) Federal requirements with respect to catch 18
and release. 19
(d) P UBLIC COMMENT .—The Secretaries shall de- 20
velop a process to allow members of the public to submit 21
questions or comments regarding the information de-22
scribed in subsections (a) and (b). 23
(e) U PDATES .—The Secretaries, to the maximum ex- 24
tent practicable, shall update— 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00006 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H187.RFS H187ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
7 
HR 187 RFS(1) the data described in subsections (a) and 1
(b) not less frequently than 2 times per year; and 2
(2) the data described in subsection (c) in real 3
time as changes go into effect. 4
(f) E XCLUSION .—This section shall not apply to irri- 5
gation canals and flowage easements. 6
(g) D ISCLOSURE .—Any geographic information sys- 7
tem data made publicly available under this section shall 8
not disclose information regarding the nature, location, 9
character, or ownership of historic, paleontological, or ar-10
chaeological resources, consistent with applicable law. 11
SEC. 5. COOPERATION AND COORDINATION. 12
(a) C OMMUNITY PARTNERS AND THIRD -PARTY PRO- 13
VIDERS .—For purposes of carrying out this Act, the Sec- 14
retaries may— 15
(1) coordinate and partner with non-Federal 16
agencies and private sector and nonprofit partners, 17
including— 18
(A) State natural resource agencies; 19
(B) Tribal natural resource agencies; 20
(C) technology companies; 21
(D) geospatial data companies; and 22
(E) experts in data science, analytics, and 23
operations research; and 24
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00007 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H187.RFS H187ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
8 
HR 187 RFS(2) enter into an agreement with a third party 1
to carry out any provision of this Act. 2
(b) U NITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY .—The 3
Secretaries may work with the Director of the United 4
States Geological Survey to collect, aggregate, digitize, 5
standardize, and publish data on behalf of the Secretaries 6
to meet the requirements of this Act. 7
(c) R EQUIREMENT .—With respect to data developed 8
and distributed under this Act, the Secretaries shall— 9
(1) develop the data in accordance with applica- 10
ble Federal, State, and Tribal laws (including regu- 11
lations); and 12
(2) include a notice that any geospatial data 13
are subject to applicable Federal, State, and Tribal 14
laws (including regulations). 15
(d) E XISTING EFFORTS .—To the extent practicable, 16
the Secretary concerned shall use or incorporate existing 17
applicable data, maps, and resources in carrying out this 18
Act, including data, maps, and resources developed and 19
published under— 20
(1) the Modernizing Access to Our Public Land 21
Act (16 U.S.C. 6851 et seq.); 22
(2) section 103 of division DD of the Consoli- 23
dated Appropriations Act, 2023 (43 U.S.C. 776); or 24
(3) other applicable law. 25

HR 187 RFSSEC. 6. REPORTS. 1
Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment 2
of this Act and annually thereafter through March 30, 3
2034, the Secretaries shall submit a report that describes 4
the progress made by the Secretaries with respect to meet-5
ing the requirements of this Act to— 6
(1) the Committee on Natural Resources of the 7
House of Representatives; 8
(2) the Committee on Energy and Commerce of 9
the House of Representatives; 10
(3) the Committee on Agriculture of the House 11
of Representatives; 12
(4) the Committee on Energy and Natural Re- 13
sources of the Senate; and 14
(5) the Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, 15
and Forestry of the Senate. 16
SEC. 7. EFFECT. 17
Nothing in this Act— 18
(1) modifies or alters the definition of the term 19
‘‘navigable waters’’ under Federal law; 20
(2) affects the jurisdiction or authority of State 21
or Federal agencies to regulate navigable waters; 22
(3) modifies or alters the authority or jurisdic- 23
tion of Federal or State agencies to manage fish- 24
eries; or 25

HR 187 RFS(4) authorizes or is intended to result in a 1
change in the accessibility of waters open to hunting, 2
fishing, or other forms of outdoor recreation as of 3
the date of the enactment of this Act. 4

1STSESSION  H. R. 197

and Forestry 
AN ACT 
To provide for a land exchange in the Chippewa National 
Forest, Minnesota, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H197.RFS H197ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
2 
HR 197 RFSSECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 1
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Lake Winnibigoshish 2
Land Exchange Act of 2025’’. 3
SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. 4
In this Act: 5
(1) BWLT.—The term ‘‘BWLT’’ means Big 6
Winnie Land and Timber, LLC, a Minnesota Lim- 7
ited Liability Corporation. 8
(2) M AP.—The term ‘‘Map’’ means the map en- 9
titled ‘‘Heig Land Exchange’’ and dated December 10
14, 2023. 11
(3) F EDERAL LAND .—The term ‘‘Federal land’’ 12
means the approximately 17.5 acres of Federal land 13
in Itasca County, Minnesota, generally depicted as 14
the ‘‘Federal Parcel’’ on the Map. 15
(4) N ON-FEDERAL LAND .—The term ‘‘non-Fed- 16
eral land’’ means the approximately 36.7 acres of 17
non-Federal land in Itasca County, Minnesota, gen- 18
erally depicted as the ‘‘Non-Federal Parcel’’ on the 19
Map. 20
(5) S ECRETARY .—The term ‘‘Secretary’’ means 21
the Secretary of Agriculture, acting through the 22
Chief of the Forest Service. 23
SEC. 3. EXCHANGE OF LAND. 24
(a) E XCHANGE AUTHORIZED .—Subject to the provi- 25
sions of this Act, if BWLT offers to convey the non-Fed-26
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H197.RFS H197ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
3 
HR 197 RFSeral land to the United States, the Secretary shall, not 1
later than 1 year after the date on which such offer is 2
made— 3
(1) accept the offer; 4
(2) convey to BWLT all right, title, and inter- 5
est of the United States in and to the Federal land, 6
excepting and reserving an easement for road access 7
to National Forest System land west of the Federal 8
Parcel; and 9
(3) accept from BWLT all right, title, and in- 10
terest of BWLT in and to the non-Federal land. 11
(b) R EQUIREMENTS .—The exchange under sub- 12
section (a) shall be— 13
(1) conditioned on title approval for the non- 14
Federal land by the Secretary in accordance with 15
subsection (e); 16
(2) conditioned on a cash equalization payment 17
made by BWLT to the United States in accordance 18
with subsection (c) if, under the appraisals con- 19
ducted in accordance with this Act, it is determined 20
that the value of the Federal land exceeds the value 21
of the non-Federal land; 22
(3) conditioned on the satisfactory completion 23
of a Phase I Environmental Site Assessment by 24
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00003 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H197.RFS H197ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
4 
HR 197 RFSBWLT, provided to the Secretary, in advance of the 1
acceptance of the non-Federal parcel; 2
(4) subject to valid existing rights; and 3
(5) subject to any other terms and conditions 4
the Secretary determines appropriate. 5
(c) E QUAL VALUE AND CASHEQUALIZATION .— 6
(1) I N GENERAL .—Except as provided in para- 7
graph (2), the exchange under subsection (a) shall 8
be for equal value or the values shall be equalized 9
by a cash payment. 10
(2) E XCEPTION .—Notwithstanding any other 11
provision of law, if the appraised value of the non- 12
Federal land to be conveyed to the United States ex- 13
ceeds the appraised value of the Federal land, a cash 14
equalization payment by the United States to 15
BWLT is hereby waived and the amount of such 16
waived payment shall be considered a donation by 17
BWLT to the United States for all purposes of law. 18
(d) A PPRAISALS .— 19
(1) I N GENERAL .—The value of the land to be 20
exchanged under this Act shall be determined by ap- 21
praisals conducted by an independent and qualified 22
appraiser mutually agreed to by the Secretary and 23
BWLT. 24
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00004 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H197.RFS H197ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
5 
HR 197 RFS(2) A PPRAISAL STANDARDS .—The Secretary 1
shall complete appraisals of the land to be ex- 2
changed under this Act in accordance with— 3
(A) the Uniform Appraisal Standards for 4
Federal Land Acquisitions; and 5
(B) the Uniform Standards of Professional 6
Appraisal Practice. 7
(e) F ORMAT .—Title to the non-Federal land to be 8
conveyed to the United States under this Act shall be 9
found sufficient by the Secretary pursuant to section 3111 10
of title 40, United States Code. 11
(f) M ANAGEMENT OF ACQUIRED LAND.—The non- 12
Federal land acquired by the United States under sub-13
section (a) shall be— 14
(1) added to, and managed as part of, the 15
Chippewa National Forest; and 16
(2) managed in accordance with the laws, rules, 17
and regulations pertaining to National Forest Sys- 18
tem lands. 19
(g) M AP AND LEGAL DESCRIPTIONS .— 20
(1) I N GENERAL .—As soon as practicable after 21
the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary 22
shall finalize the Map and legal descriptions of all 23
land to be conveyed under this Act. 24
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00005 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H197.RFS H197ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
6 
HR 197 RFS(2) C ONTROLLING DOCUMENT .—In the case of 1
a discrepancy between the Map and a legal descrip- 2
tion, the Map shall control. 3
(3) C ORRECTIONS .—The Secretary and BWLT, 4
by mutual agreement, may correct any minor errors 5
in the Map or in the legal descriptions, including 6
with respect to the boundaries of the Federal land 7
and the non-Federal land. 8
(4) M AP ON FILE .—The Map and legal descrip- 9
tions shall be on file and available for public inspec- 10
tion in appropriate offices of the Forest Service. 11
(h) C LOSING COSTS .—As a condition for the ex- 12
change under subsection (a), BWLT shall pay all closing 13
costs associated with the exchange, including for— 14
(1) title insurance and title search; 15
(2) any applicable inspection fees, escrow fees, 16
attorneys fees, and recording fees; and 17
(3) any environmental analysis or resource sur- 18
vey required under Federal law, regulation, or pol- 19
icy, including a Phase I Environmental Site Assess- 20
ment of the non-Federal land. 21
(i) S URVEY .— 22
(1) I N GENERAL .—The exact acreages and legal 23
descriptions of the Federal and non-Federal land to 24

Received; read twice and referred to the Committee on Energy and Natural 
Resources 
AN ACT 
To require that the Secretary of Agriculture and the Sec-
retary of the Interior submit accurate reports regarding hazardous fuels reduction activities, and for other pur-poses. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H204.RFS H204ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
2 
HR 204 RFSSECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 1
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Accurately Counting 2
Risk Elimination Solutions Act’’ or the ‘‘ACRES Act’’. 3
SEC. 2. ACCURATE HAZARDOUS FUELS REDUCTION RE-4
PORTS. 5
(a) I NCLUSION OF HAZARDOUS FUELS REDUCTION  6
REPORT IN MATERIALS SUBMITTED IN SUPPORT OF THE  7
PRESIDENT ’SBUDGET .— 8
(1) I N GENERAL .—Beginning with the first fis- 9
cal year that begins after the date of the enactment 10
of this Act, and each fiscal year thereafter, the Sec- 11
retary concerned shall include in the materials sub- 12
mitted in support of the President’s budget pursuant 13
to section 1105 of title 31, United States Code, a re- 14
port on the number of acres of Federal land on 15
which the Secretary concerned carried out hazardous 16
fuels reduction activities during the preceding fiscal 17
year. 18
(2) R EQUIREMENTS .—For purposes of the re- 19
port required under paragraph (1), the Secretary 20
concerned shall— 21
(A) in determining the number of acres of 22
Federal land on which the Secretary concerned 23
carried out hazardous fuels reduction activities 24
during the period covered by the report— 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H204.RFS H204ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
3 
HR 204 RFS(i) record acres of Federal land on 1
which hazardous fuels reduction activities 2
were completed during such period; and 3
(ii) record each acre described in 4
clause (i) once in the report, regardless of 5
whether multiple hazardous fuels reduction 6
activities were carried out on such acre 7
during such period; and 8
(B) with respect to the acres of Federal 9
land recorded in the report, include information 10
on— 11
(i) which such acres are located in the 12
wildland-urban interface; 13
(ii) the level of wildfire risk (high, 14
moderate, or low) on the first and last day 15
of the period covered by the report; 16
(iii) the types of hazardous fuels ac- 17
tivities completed for such acres, delin- 18
eating between whether such activities 19
were conducted— 20
(I) in a wildfire managed for re- 21
source benefits; or 22
(II) through a planned project; 23
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00003 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H204.RFS H204ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
4 
HR 204 RFS(iv) the cost per acre of hazardous 1
fuels activities carried out during the pe- 2
riod covered by the report; 3
(v) the region or system unit in which 4
the acres are located; and 5
(vi) the effectiveness of the hazardous 6
fuels reduction activities on reducing the 7
risk of wildfire. 8
(3) T RANSPARENCY .—The Secretary concerned 9
shall make each report submitted under paragraph 10
(1) publicly available on the website of the Depart- 11
ment of Agriculture and the Department of the Inte- 12
rior, as applicable. 13
(b) A CCURATE DATACOLLECTION .— 14
(1) I N GENERAL .—Not later than 90 days after 15
the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary 16
concerned shall implement standardized procedures 17
for tracking data related to hazardous fuels reduc- 18
tion activities carried out by the Secretary con- 19
cerned. 20
(2) E LEMENTS .—The standardized procedures 21
required under paragraph (1) shall include— 22
(A) regular, standardized data reviews of 23
the accuracy and timely input of data used to 24
track hazardous fuels reduction activities; 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00004 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H204.RFS H204ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
5 
HR 204 RFS(B) verification methods that validate 1
whether such data accurately correlates to the 2
hazardous fuels reduction activities carried out 3
by the Secretary concerned; 4
(C) an analysis of the short- and long-term 5
effectiveness of the hazardous fuels reduction 6
activities on reducing the risk of wildfire; and 7
(D) for hazardous fuels reduction activities 8
that occur partially within the wildland-urban 9
interface, methods to distinguish which acres 10
are located within the wildland-urban interface 11
and which acres are located outside the 12
wildland-urban interface. 13
(3) R EPORT .—Not later than 2 weeks after im- 14
plementing the standardized procedures required 15
under paragraph (1), the Secretary concerned shall 16
submit to Congress a report that describes— 17
(A) such standardized procedures; and 18
(B) program and policy recommendations 19
to Congress to address any limitations in track- 20
ing data related to hazardous fuels reduction 21
activities under this subsection. 22
(c) GAO S TUDY .—Not later than 2 years after the 23
date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General 24
of the United States shall— 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00005 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H204.RFS H204ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
6 
HR 204 RFS(1) conduct a study on the implementation of 1
this Act, including any limitations with respect to— 2
(A) reporting hazardous fuels reduction ac- 3
tivities under subsection (a); or 4
(B) tracking data related to hazardous 5
fuels reduction activities under subsection (b); 6
and 7
(2) submit to Congress a report that describes 8
the results of the study under paragraph (1). 9
(d) D EFINITIONS .—In this Act: 10
(1) H AZARDOUS FUELS REDUCTION ACTIV - 11
ITY.—The term ‘‘hazardous fuels reduction activ- 12
ity’’— 13
(A) means any vegetation management ac- 14
tivity to reduce the risk of wildfire, including 15
mechanical treatments and prescribed burning; 16
and 17
(B) does not include the awarding of con- 18
tracts to conduct hazardous fuels reduction ac- 19
tivities. 20
(2) F EDERAL LANDS .—The term ‘‘Federal 21
lands’’ means lands under the jurisdiction of the 22
Secretary of the Interior or the Secretary of Agri- 23
culture. 24
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00006 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H204.RFS H204ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
7 
HR 204 RFS(3) S ECRETARY CONCERNED .—The term ‘‘Sec- 1
retary concerned’’ means— 2
(A) the Secretary of Agriculture, with re- 3
spect to National Forest System lands; and 4
(B) the Secretary of the Interior, with re- 5
spect to public lands and units of the National 6
Park System. 7
(4) W ILDLAND -URBAN INTERFACE .—The term 8
‘‘wildland-urban interface’’ has the meaning given 9
the term in section 101 of the Healthy Forests Res- 10
toration Act of 2003 (16 U.S.C. 6511). 11
(e) N OADDITIONAL FUNDS AUTHORIZED .—No addi- 12
tional funds are authorized to carry out the requirements 13
of this Act, and the activities authorized by this Act are 14
subject to the availability of appropriations made in ad-15
vance for such purposes. 16

and Transportation 
AN ACT 
To direct the Secretary of Commerce to establish a task 
force regarding shark depredation, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:54 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H207.RFS H207ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
2 
HR 207 RFSSECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 1
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Supporting the Health 2
of Aquatic systems through Research Knowledge and En-3
hanced Dialogue Act of 2025’’ or the ‘‘SHARKED Act 4
of 2025’’. 5
SEC. 2. SHARK DEPREDATION TASK FORCE AND RESEARCH 6
PROJECTS. 7
(a) S HARK DEPREDATION TASKFORCE .— 8
(1) I N GENERAL .—The Secretary of Commerce 9
shall establish a task force (referred to in this sub- 10
section as the ‘‘task force’’) to identify and address 11
critical needs with respect to shark depredation. 12
(2) M EMBERSHIP .—The Secretary of Com- 13
merce shall appoint individuals to the task force, in- 14
cluding— 15
(A) 1 representative from— 16
(i) each Regional Fishery Manage- 17
ment Council established under section 18
302(a)(1) of the Magnuson-Stevens Fish- 19
ery Conservation and Management Act (16 20
U.S.C. 1852(a)(1)); 21
(ii) each Marine Fisheries Commis- 22
sion, as such term is defined in section 3 23
of the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Con- 24
servation and Management Act (16 U.S.C. 25
1802); 26
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:54 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H207.RFS H207ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
3 
HR 207 RFS(iii) the fish and wildlife agency of a 1
coastal State from each Regional Fishery 2
Management Council established under 3
section 302(a)(1) of the Magnuson-Stevens 4
Fishery Conservation and Management Act 5
(16 U.S.C. 1852(a)(1)); and 6
(iv) the National Marine Fisheries 7
Service; 8
(B) an individual with expertise in the 9
management of highly migratory species; 10
(C) a researcher with expertise in shark 11
management and behavior; and 12
(D) a researcher with expertise in shark 13
ecology. 14
(3) R ESPONSIBILITIES .—The task force shall— 15
(A) develop ways to improve coordination 16
and communication across the fisheries man- 17
agement community and shark research com- 18
munity to address shark depredation; 19
(B) identify research priorities and funding 20
opportunities for such priorities, including— 21
(i) identifying shark species involved 22
in interactions; 23
(ii) shark stock assessments; 24
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:54 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00003 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H207.RFS H207ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
4 
HR 207 RFS(iii) how sharks become habituated to 1
humans and thus lead to more interactions 2
between sharks and humans; 3
(iv) how angler behavior and fishery 4
regulatory frameworks may influence shark 5
interactions; 6
(v) techniques and strategies to re- 7
duce harmful interactions between sharks 8
and humans, including the development 9
and use of non-lethal deterrents; 10
(vi) the role of healthy shark popu- 11
lations in the ocean food web; and 12
(vii) climate change impacts on shift- 13
ing shark populations, prey, and shark be- 14
havior; 15
(C) develop recommended management 16
strategies to address shark depredation; and 17
(D) coordinate the development and dis- 18
tribution of educational materials to help the 19
fishing community minimize shark interactions 20
including through changed angler behavior and 21
expectations. 22
(4) R EPORT .—Not later than 2 years after the 23
date of the enactment of this section, and every 2 24
years thereafter until the termination of the task 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:54 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00004 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H207.RFS H207ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
5 
HR 207 RFSforce in accordance with paragraph (5), the task 1
force shall submit to Congress a report regarding 2
the findings of the task force. 3
(5) S UNSET .—The task force shall terminate 4
not later than 7 years after the date on which the 5
Secretary of Commerce establishes the task force. 6
(6) C OASTAL STATE DEFINED .—In this sub- 7
section, the term ‘‘coastal State’’— 8
(A) means a State of the United States in, 9
or bordering on, the Atlantic Ocean, Pacific 10
Ocean, Arctic Ocean, Gulf of Mexico, or Long 11
Island Sound; and 12
(B) includes Puerto Rico, the Virgin Is- 13
lands of the United States, Guam, the Com- 14
monwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, 15
and American Samoa. 16
(b) S HARK DEPREDATION RESEARCH PROJECTS .— 17
Section 318(c) of the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Con-18
servation and Management Act (16 U.S.C. 1867(c)) is 19
amended by adding at the end the following: 20
‘‘(6) Projects to better understand shark depre- 21
dation, including identifying what causes increases 22
in shark depredation and determining how to best 23
address shark depredation.’’. 24

A BILL 
To prohibit taxpayer funded abortions. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
VerDate Sep 11 2014 01:34 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H7.IH H7kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
2 
•HR 7 IHSECTION 1. SHORT TITLE; TABLE OF CONTENTS. 1
(a) S HORT TITLE.—This Act may be cited as the 2
‘‘No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion and Abortion Insur-3
ance Full Disclosure Act of 2025’’. 4
(b) T ABLE OF CONTENTS .—The table of contents of 5
this Act is as follows: 6
Sec. 1. Short title; table of contents. 
TITLE I—PROHIBITING FEDERALLY FUNDED ABORTIONS 
Sec. 101. Prohibiting taxpayer funded abortions. 
Sec. 102. Amendment to table of chapters. 
TITLE II—APPLICATION UNDER THE AFFORDABLE CARE ACT 
Sec. 201. Clarifying application of prohibition to premium credits and cost- 
sharing reductions under ACA. 
Sec. 202. Revision of notice requirements regarding disclosure of extent of 
health plan coverage of abortion and abortion premium sur-charges. 
TITLE I—PROHIBITING FEDER-7
ALLY FUNDED ABORTIONS 8
SEC. 101. PROHIBITING TAXPAYER FUNDED ABORTIONS. 9
Title 1, United States Code, is amended by adding 10
at the end the following new chapter: 11
‘‘CHAPTER 4—PROHIBITING TAXPAYER 12
FUNDED ABORTIONS 13
‘‘301. Prohibition on funding for abortions. 
‘‘302. Prohibition on funding for health benefits plans that cover abortion. ‘‘303. Limitation on Federal facilities and employees. ‘‘304. Construction relating to separate coverage. ‘‘305. Construction relating to the use of non-Federal funds for health coverage. ‘‘306. Non-preemption of other Federal laws. ‘‘307. Construction relating to complications arising from abortion. ‘‘308. Treatment of abortions related to rape, incest, or preserving the life of 
the mother. 
‘‘309. Application to District of Columbia. 
VerDate Sep 11 2014 01:34 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6211 E:\BILLS\H7.IH H7kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
3 
•HR 7 IH‘‘§ 301. Prohibition on funding for abortions 1
‘‘No funds authorized or appropriated by Federal 2
law, and none of the funds in any trust fund to which 3
funds are authorized or appropriated by Federal law, shall 4
be expended for any abortion. 5
‘‘§ 302. Prohibition on funding for health benefits 6
plans that cover abortion 7
‘‘None of the funds authorized or appropriated by 8
Federal law, and none of the funds in any trust fund to 9
which funds are authorized or appropriated by Federal 10
law, shall be expended for health benefits coverage that 11
includes coverage of abortion. 12
‘‘§ 303. Limitation on Federal facilities and employees 13
‘‘No health care service furnished— 14
‘‘(1) by or in a health care facility owned or op- 15
erated by the Federal Government; or 16
‘‘(2) by any physician or other individual em- 17
ployed by the Federal Government to provide health 18
care services within the scope of the physician’s or 19
individual’s employment, 20
may include abortion. 21
‘‘§ 304. Construction relating to separate coverage 22
‘‘Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as pro- 23
hibiting any individual, entity, or State or locality from 24
purchasing separate abortion coverage or health benefits 25
coverage that includes abortion so long as such coverage 26
VerDate Sep 11 2014 01:34 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00003 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H7.IH H7kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
4 
•HR 7 IHis paid for entirely using only funds not authorized or ap-1
propriated by Federal law and such coverage shall not be 2
purchased using matching funds required for a federally 3
subsidized program, including a State’s or locality’s con-4
tribution of Medicaid matching funds. 5
‘‘§ 305. Construction relating to the use of non-Fed-6
eral funds for health coverage 7
‘‘Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as re- 8
stricting the ability of any non-Federal health benefits cov-9
erage provider from offering abortion coverage, or the abil-10
ity of a State or locality to contract separately with such 11
a provider for such coverage, so long as only funds not 12
authorized or appropriated by Federal law are used and 13
such coverage shall not be purchased using matching 14
funds required for a federally subsidized program, includ-15
ing a State’s or locality’s contribution of Medicaid match-16
ing funds. 17
‘‘§ 306. Non-preemption of other Federal laws 18
‘‘Nothing in this chapter shall repeal, amend, or have 19
any effect on any other Federal law to the extent such 20
law imposes any limitation on the use of funds for abortion 21
or for health benefits coverage that includes coverage of 22
abortion, beyond the limitations set forth in this chapter. 23
VerDate Sep 11 2014 01:34 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00004 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H7.IH H7kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
5 
•HR 7 IH‘‘§ 307. Construction relating to complications arising 1
from abortion 2
‘‘Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to apply 3
to the treatment of any infection, injury, disease, or dis-4
order that has been caused by or exacerbated by the per-5
formance of an abortion. This rule of construction shall 6
be applicable without regard to whether the abortion was 7
performed in accord with Federal or State law, and with-8
out regard to whether funding for the abortion is permis-9
sible under section 308. 10
‘‘§ 308. Treatment of abortions related to rape, incest, 11
or preserving the life of the mother 12
‘‘The limitations established in sections 301, 302, 13
and 303 shall not apply to an abortion— 14
‘‘(1) if the pregnancy is the result of an act of 15
rape or incest; or 16
‘‘(2) in the case where a woman suffers from a 17
physical disorder, physical injury, or physical illness 18
that would, as certified by a physician, place the 19
woman in danger of death unless an abortion is per- 20
formed, including a life-endangering physical condi- 21
tion caused by or arising from the pregnancy itself. 22
‘‘§ 309. Application to District of Columbia 23
‘‘In this chapter: 24
‘‘(1) Any reference to funds appropriated by 25
Federal law shall be treated as including any 26
VerDate Sep 11 2014 01:34 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00005 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H7.IH H7kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
6 
•HR 7 IHamounts within the budget of the District of Colum- 1
bia that have been approved by an Act of Congress 2
pursuant to section 446 of the District of Columbia 3
Home Rule Act (or any applicable successor Federal 4
law). 5
‘‘(2) The term ‘Federal Government’ includes 6
the Government of the District of Columbia.’’. 7

II 
Calendar No. 5 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  S. RES. 29 
Expressing the sense of the Senate that the President of the United States 
possesses legal authority under existing law to take immediate and nec-essary action to secure the southwest border of the United States. 
IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES 
JANUARY 21, 2025 
Mr. P AUL, from the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Af-
fairs, reported the following original resolution; which was placed on the calendar 
RESOLUTION 
Expressing the sense of the Senate that the President of 
the United States possesses legal authority under exist-ing law to take immediate and necessary action to secure the southwest border of the United States. 
Whereas, since the start of the Biden-Harris Administration, 
nearly 11,000,000 individuals have been encountered at-tempting to enter the United States unlawfully; 
Whereas U.S. Customs and Border Protection has— 
(1) apprehended nearly 400 suspected terrorists at-
tempting to enter the United States illegally between ports of entry; 
VerDate Sep 11 2014 02:07 Jan 22, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6300 E:\BILLS\SR29.RS SR29ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
2 
•SRES 29 RS (2) encountered an additional 1,587 suspected ter-
rorists at United States ports of entry; and 
(3) identified more than 1,700,000 special interest 
aliens; 
Whereas, since October 1, 2021, more than 120,000 illegal 
aliens with criminal warrants or convictions were encoun-tered along United States borders, including— 
(1) more than 4,800 illegal aliens who were con-
victed of assault, battery, or domestic violence; 
(2) more than 3,300 illegal aliens who were con-
victed of theft-related offenses; 
(3) nearly 1,400 illegal aliens who were convicted of 
sexual offenses; and 
(4) nearly 200 illegal aliens who were convicted of 
homicide or manslaughter; 
Whereas, under section 235(b)(2)(C) of the Immigration and 
Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1225(b)(2)(C)), the Depart-ment of Homeland Security is authorized to immediately return certain applicants for admission or asylum to a contiguous foreign territory in accordance with the memorandum from the Secretary of Homeland Security entitled ‘‘Policy Guidance for Implementation of the Mi-grant Protection Protocols’’, dated January 25, 2019, or any substantially similar policy changes issued or taken on or after January 20, 2025, whether set forth in a memorandum, executive order, regulation, directive, or by other action; 
Whereas, under section 212(f) of such Act (8 U.S.C. 
1182(f)), the President has been given broad authority to suspend the entry of all aliens, or to impose any restric-tions upon the entry of aliens the President deems appro-priate, allowing the President to bar the entry of nation-
VerDate Sep 11 2014 02:07 Jan 22, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6300 E:\BILLS\SR29.RS SR29ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
3 
•SRES 29 RS als whose admission could be detrimental to the interests 
of the United States; 
Whereas, under section 208(b)(2)(C) of such Act (8 U.S.C. 
1158(b)(2)(C)), the Department of Homeland Security is authorized to promulgate additional limitations and con-ditions under which an alien shall be ineligible for asy-lum, including making asylum seekers ineligible if they enter or attempt to enter the United States across the southern border without first applying for protection from persecution or torture in at least 1 country, other than the alien’s country of citizenship, nationality, or last lawful habitual residence, through which the alien transited en route to the United States; and 
Whereas the ‘‘Remain in Mexico’’ policy (also known as the 
Migrant Protection Protocols) was an effective measure that enhanced border security, helped deter illegal en-tries, and made the United States safer: Now, therefore, be it 
Resolved, That the Senate— 1
(1) affirms that the President has the authority 2
under the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 3
U.S.C. 1101 et seq.), including sections 4
208(a)(2)(A), 212(f), and 235(b)(2)(C) (8 U.S.C. 5
1158(a)(2)(A), 1182(f), and 1225(b)(2)(C)) to take 6
action to secure the southern border and protect the 7
sovereignty and security of the United States; and 8
(2) urges the President and the Secretary of 9
Homeland Security to utilize all available statutory 10
authority to expeditiously reinstate or implement 11
VerDate Sep 11 2014 02:07 Jan 22, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00003 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\SR29.RS SR29ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
4 
•SRES 29 RS policies and programs that will promote orderly and 1
lawful entry at the border, deter illegal immigration, 2
and protect national security, including by— 3
(A) immediately removing illegal aliens; 4
(B) immediately returning illegal aliens to 5
Mexico; 6
(C) reinstating the Migrant Protection 7
Protocols (commonly known as ‘‘Remain in 8
Mexico’’) or any substantially similar policy; 9
(D) ending the catch-and-release policy; 10
(E) ending abuses of humanitarian parole 11
authority; 12
(F) detaining inadmissible aliens; 13
(G) making illegal aliens ineligible for asy- 14
lum; 15
(H) using expedited removal authority; and 16
(I) eliminating taxpayer-funded benefits 17
for illegal aliens. 18

119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 30 
IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES 
JANUARY 17, 2025 
Received; read twice and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary 
AN ACT 
To amend the Immigration and Nationality Act to provide 
that aliens who have been convicted of or who have committed sex offenses or domestic violence are inadmis-sible and deportable. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
VerDate Sep 11 2014 20:30 Jan 17, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H30.RFS H30ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
2 
HR 30 RFSSECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 1
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Preventing Violence 2
Against Women by Illegal Aliens Act’’. 3
SEC. 2. INADMISSIBILITY AND DEPORTABILITY RELATED 4
TO SEX OFFENSES, DOMESTIC VIOLENCE, 5
STALKING, CHILD ABUSE, OR VIOLATION OF 6
PROTECTION ORDER. 7
(a) I NADMISSIBILITY .—Section 212(a)(2) of the Im- 8
migration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1182(a)(2)) is 9
amended by adding at the end the following: 10
‘‘(J) S EX OFFENSES .—Any alien who has 11
been convicted of, who admits having com- 12
mitted, or who admits committing acts which 13
constitute the essential elements of a sex of- 14
fense (as such term is defined in section 111(5) 15
of the Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety 16
Act of 2006 (34 U.S.C. 20911(5))), or a con- 17
spiracy to commit such an offense, is inadmis- 18
sible. 19
‘‘(K) D OMESTIC VIOLENCE , STALKING , 20
CHILD ABUSE , OR VIOLATION OF PROTECTION  21
ORDER .—Any alien who has been convicted of, 22
who admits having committed, or who admits 23
committing acts which constitute the essential 24
elements of— 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 20:30 Jan 17, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H30.RFS H30ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
3 
HR 30 RFS‘‘(i) a crime of domestic violence (as 1
such term is defined in section 2
237(a)(2)(E)); 3
‘‘(ii) a crime of stalking; 4
‘‘(iii) a crime of child abuse, child ne- 5
glect, or child abandonment; or 6
‘‘(iv) a crime of violating the portion 7
of a protection order (as such term is de- 8
fined in section 237(a)(2)(E)) that involves 9
protection against credible threats of vio- 10
lence, repeated harassment, or bodily in- 11
jury to the person or persons for whom the 12
protection order was issued, 13
is inadmissible.’’. 14
(b) D EPORTABILITY .—Section 237(a)(2) of the Im- 15
migration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1227(a)(2)) is 16
amended— 17
(1) in subparagraph (E)— 18
(A) in the heading, by striking ‘‘ CRIMES  19
AGAINST CHILDREN AND ’’ and inserting ‘‘ AND 20
CRIMES AGAINST CHILDREN ’’; and 21
(B) in clause (i), by inserting before the 22
period at the end the following ‘‘, and includes 23
any crime that constitutes domestic violence, as 24
such term is defined in section 40002(a) of the 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 20:30 Jan 17, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00003 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H30.RFS H30ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS

HR 30 RFSViolent Crime Control and Law Enforcement 1
Act of 1994 (34 U.S.C. 12291(a)), regardless 2
of whether the jurisdiction receives grant fund- 3

(2) by adding at the end the following: 5
‘‘(G) S EX OFFENSES .—Any alien who has 6
been convicted of a sex offense (as such term is 7
defined in section 111(5) of the Adam Walsh 8
Child Protection and Safety Act of 2006 (34 9
U.S.C. 20911(5))) or a conspiracy to commit 10
such an offense, is deportable.’’. 11

IIB 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 33 
IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES 
JANUARY 16, 2025 
Received; read twice and referred to the Committee on Finance 
AN ACT 
To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide 
special rules for the taxation of certain residents of Tai-wan with income from sources within the United States. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

HR 33 RFSTITLE I—UNITED STATES-TAI-1
WAN EXPEDITED DOUBLE- 2
TAX RELIEF ACT 3
SEC. 101. SHORT TITLE. 4
This title may be cited as the ‘‘United States-Taiwan 5
Expedited Double-Tax Relief Act’’. 6
SEC. 102. SPECIAL RULES FOR TAXATION OF CERTAIN 7
RESIDENTS OF TAIWAN. 8
(a) I NGENERAL .—Subpart D of part II of sub- 9
chapter N of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 10
1986 is amended by inserting after section 894 the fol-11
lowing new section: 12
‘‘SEC. 894A. SPECIAL RULES FOR QUALIFIED RESIDENTS OF 13
TAIWAN. 14
‘‘(a) C ERTAIN INCOME FROM UNITED STATES  15
SOURCES .— 16
‘‘(1) I NTEREST , DIVIDENDS , AND ROYALTIES , 17
ETC.— 18
‘‘(A) I N GENERAL .—In the case of interest 19
(other than original issue discount), dividends, 20
royalties, amounts described in section 21
871(a)(1)(C), and gains described in section 22
871(a)(1)(D) received by or paid to a qualified 23
resident of Taiwan— 24

1441(c)(5), and 1442(a) shall each be ap- 2
plied by substituting ‘the applicable per- 3
centage (as defined in section 4
894A(a)(1)(C))’ for ‘30 percent’ each place 5
it appears, and 6

1441(c)(1) shall each be applied by sub- 8

tablishment of a qualified resident of Tai- 10
wan’ for ‘a trade or business within the 11
United States’ each place it appears. 12

shall not apply to— 15

tion 897, 21

‘‘(ii) Q UALIFIED REIT DIVIDEND .— 8
For purposes of clause (i)(I), the term 9
‘qualified REIT dividend’ means any divi- 10
dend received from or paid by a real estate 11
investment trust if such dividend is paid 12
with respect to a class of shares that is 13
publicly traded and the recipient of the 14
dividend is a person who holds an interest 15
in any class of shares of the real estate in- 16
vestment trust of not more than 5 percent. 17
‘‘(C) A PPLICABLE PERCENTAGE .—For 18
purposes of applying subparagraph (A)(i)— 19
‘‘(i) I N GENERAL .—Except as pro- 20
vided in clause (ii), the term ‘applicable 21
percentage’ means 10 percent. 22
‘‘(ii) S PECIAL RULES FOR DIVI - 23
DENDS .— In the case of any dividend in 24
respect of stock received by or paid to a 25

HR 33 RFSqualified resident of Taiwan, the applicable 1
percentage shall be 15 percent (10 percent 2
in the case of a dividend which meets the 3
requirements of subparagraph (D) and is 4
received by or paid to an entity taxed as 5
a corporation in Taiwan). 6
‘‘(D) R EQUIREMENTS FOR LOWER DIVI - 7
DEND RATE .— 8
‘‘(i) I N GENERAL .—The requirements 9
of this subparagraph are met with respect 10
to any dividend in respect of stock in a 11
corporation if, at all times during the 12- 12
month period ending on the date such 13
stock becomes ex-dividend with respect to 14
such dividend— 15
‘‘(I) the dividend is derived by a 16
qualified resident of Taiwan, and 17
‘‘(II) such qualified resident of 18
Taiwan has held directly at least 10 19
percent (by vote and value) of the 20
total outstanding shares of stock in 21
such corporation. 22
For purposes of subclause (II), a person 23
shall be treated as directly holding a share 24
of stock during any period described in the 25

a corporation from which such person later 2
acquired that share and such corporation 3

‘‘(ii) E XCEPTION FOR RICS AND  7

be treated as met with respect to any divi- 10

‘‘(2) Q UALIFIED WAGES .— 13
‘‘(A) I N GENERAL .—No tax shall be im- 14
posed under this chapter (and no amount shall 15
be withheld under section 1441(a) or chapter 16
24) with respect to qualified wages paid to a 17
qualified resident of Taiwan who— 18
‘‘(i) is not a resident of the United 19
States (determined without regard to sub- 20
section (c)(3)(E)), or 21
‘‘(ii) is employed as a member of the 22
regular component of a ship or aircraft op- 23
erated in international traffic. 24
‘‘(B) Q UALIFIED WAGES .— 25

HR 33 RFS‘‘(i) I N GENERAL .—The term ‘quali- 1
fied wages’ means wages, salaries, or simi- 2
lar remunerations with respect to employ- 3
ment involving the performance of personal 4
services within the United States which— 5
‘‘(I) are paid by (or on behalf of) 6
any employer other than a United 7
States person, and 8
‘‘(II) are not borne by a United 9
States permanent establishment of 10
any person other than a United States 11
person. 12
‘‘(ii) E XCEPTIONS .—Such term shall 13
not include directors’ fees, income derived 14
as an entertainer or athlete, income de- 15
rived as a student or trainee, pensions, 16
amounts paid with respect to employment 17
with the United States, any State (or polit- 18
ical subdivision thereof), or any possession 19
of the United States (or any political sub- 20
division thereof), or other amounts speci- 21
fied in regulations or guidance under sub- 22
section (f)(1)(F). 23

OR ATHLETIC ACTIVITIES .— 25

posed under this chapter (and no amount shall 2

24) with respect to income derived by an enter- 4
tainer or athlete who is a qualified resident of 5
Taiwan from personal activities as such per- 6
formed in the United States if the aggregate 7

for the taxable year do not exceed $30,000. 9

shall not apply with respect to— 11
‘‘(i) income which is qualified wages 12

of), or 15

sections 871(b) and 882, a qualified resident of 24
Taiwan that carries on a trade or business 25

‘‘(B) D ETERMINATION OF TAXABLE IN - 6
COME .—In determining taxable income for pur- 7
poses of paragraph (1), gross income includes 8
only gross income which is effectively connected 9
with the permanent establishment. 10
‘‘(2) T REATMENT OF DISPOSITIONS OF UNITED  11
STATES REAL PROPERTY .—In the case of a qualified 12
resident of Taiwan, section 897(a) shall be applied— 13
‘‘(A) by substituting ‘carried on a trade or 14
business within the United States through a 15
United States permanent establishment’ for 16
‘were engaged in a trade or business within the 17
United States’, and 18
‘‘(B) by substituting ‘such United States 19
permanent establishment’ for ‘such trade or 20
business’. 21

TAXES .—In the case of any corporation which is a 23
qualified resident of Taiwan, section 884 shall be ap- 24
plied— 25

who is not the entertainer or athlete per- 18

shall not apply if the person described in sub- 21
paragraph (A)(ii) is contractually authorized to 22
designate the individual who is to perform such 23
activities. 24

‘‘(c) Q UALIFIED RESIDENT OF TAIWAN .—For pur- 7
poses of this section— 8
‘‘(1) I N GENERAL .—The term ‘qualified resi- 9
dent of Taiwan’ means any person who— 10
‘‘(A) is liable to tax under the laws of Tai- 11
wan by reason of such person’s domicile, resi- 12
dence, place of management, place of incorpora- 13
tion, or any similar criterion, 14
‘‘(B) is not a United States person (deter- 15
mined without regard to paragraph (3)(E)), 16
and 17
‘‘(C) in the case of an entity taxed as a 18
corporation in Taiwan, meets the requirements 19
of paragraph (2). 20
‘‘(2) L IMITATION ON BENEFITS FOR COR - 21
PORATE ENTITIES OF TAIWAN .— 22
‘‘(A) I N GENERAL .—Subject to subpara- 23
graphs (E) and (F), an entity meets the re- 24
quirements of this paragraph only if it— 25

requirements of subparagraph (B), 2
‘‘(ii) meets the publicly traded re- 3

‘‘(iii) meets the qualified subsidiary 5
requirements of subparagraph (D). 6
‘‘(B) O WNERSHIP AND INCOME REQUIRE - 7
MENTS .—The requirements of this subpara- 8

‘‘(i) at least 50 percent (by vote and 10

stock in such entity are owned directly or 12
indirectly by qualified residents of Taiwan, 13
and 14
‘‘(ii) less than 50 percent of such enti- 15

entity that is a member of a tested group, 17
less than 50 percent of the tested group’s 18
gross income) is paid or accrued, directly 19

are not— 23
‘‘(I) qualified residents of Tai- 24
wan, or 25

on an established securities market in Tai- 21

izen, 24

‘‘(ii) does not have a permanent home 12

‘‘(i) such individual has a permanent 17
home available to such individual in both 18
Taiwan and the United States, and 19
‘‘(ii) such individual’s personal and 20
economic relations (center of vital inter- 21
ests) are closer to Taiwan than to the 22
United States. 23

described in this subparagraph if— 25

‘‘(E) U NITED STATES TAX TREATMENT OF  14
QUALIFIED RESIDENT OF TAIWAN .—Notwith- 15
standing section 7701, an individual who is 16
treated as a qualified resident of Taiwan by 17
reason of this paragraph for all or any portion 18
of a taxable year shall not be treated as a resi- 19
dent of the United States for purposes of com- 20
puting such individual’s United States income 21
tax liability for such taxable year or portion 22
thereof. 23

HR 33 RFS‘‘(A) D IVIDENDS .—For purposes of apply- 1
ing this section to any dividend, paragraph 2
(2)(D) shall be applied without regard to clause 3
(ii) thereof. 4
‘‘(B) I TEMS OF INCOME EMANATING FROM  5
AN ACTIVE TRADE OR BUSINESS IN TAIWAN .— 6
For purposes of this section— 7
‘‘(i) I N GENERAL .—Notwithstanding 8
the preceding paragraphs of this sub- 9
section, if an entity taxed as a corporation 10
in Taiwan is not a qualified resident of 11
Taiwan but meets the requirements of sub- 12
paragraphs (A) and (B) of paragraph (1), 13
any qualified item of income such entity 14
derived from the United States shall be 15
treated as income of a qualified resident of 16
Taiwan. 17
‘‘(ii) Q UALIFIED ITEMS OF INCOME .— 18
‘‘(I) I N GENERAL .—The term 19
‘qualified item of income’ means any 20
item of income which emanates from, 21
or is incidental to, the conduct of an 22
active trade or business in Taiwan 23
(other than operating as a holding 24
company, providing overall supervision 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 17, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00019 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H33.RFS H33ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
20 
HR 33 RFSor administration of a group of com- 1
panies, providing group financing, or 2
making or managing investments (un- 3
less such making or managing invest- 4
ments is carried on by a bank, insur- 5
ance company, or registered securities 6
dealer in the ordinary course of its 7
business as such)). 8
‘‘(II) S UBSTANTIAL ACTIVITY RE - 9
QUIREMENT .—An item of income 10
which is derived from a trade or busi- 11
ness conducted in the United States 12
or from a connected person shall be a 13
qualified item of income only if the 14
trade or business activity conducted in 15
Taiwan to which the item is related is 16
substantial in relation to the same or 17
a complementary trade or business ac- 18
tivity carried on in the United States. 19
For purposes of applying this sub- 20
clause, activities conducted by persons 21
that are connected to the entity de- 22
scribed in clause (i) shall be deemed 23
to be conducted by such entity. 24

percent (by vote or value) of such entity is 4
owned (directly or indirectly) or controlled 5
by residents of a foreign country of con- 6

‘‘(d) O THER DEFINITIONS AND SPECIAL RULES .— 8
For purposes of this section— 9
‘‘(1) U NITED STATES PERMANENT ESTABLISH - 10
MENT .— 11
‘‘(A) I N GENERAL .—The term ‘United 12
States permanent establishment’ means, with 13
respect to a qualified resident of Taiwan, a per- 14
manent establishment of such resident which is 15
within the United States. 16
‘‘(B) S PECIAL RULE .—The determination 17
of whether there is a permanent establishment 18
of a qualified resident of Taiwan within the 19
United States shall be made without regard to 20
whether an entity which is taxed as a corpora- 21
tion in Taiwan and which is a qualified resident 22
of Taiwan controls or is controlled by— 23
‘‘(i) a domestic corporation, or 24
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 17, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00021 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H33.RFS H33ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
22 
HR 33 RFS‘‘(ii) any other person that carries on 1
business in the United States (whether 2
through a permanent establishment or oth- 3
erwise). 4
‘‘(2) P ERMANENT ESTABLISHMENT .— 5
‘‘(A) I N GENERAL .—The term ‘permanent 6
establishment’ means a fixed place of business 7
through which a trade or business is wholly or 8
partly carried on. Such term shall include— 9
‘‘(i) a place of management, 10
‘‘(ii) a branch, 11
‘‘(iii) an office, 12
‘‘(iv) a factory, 13
‘‘(v) a workshop, and 14
‘‘(vi) a mine, an oil or gas well, a 15
quarry, or any other place of extraction of 16
natural resources. 17
‘‘(B) S PECIAL RULES FOR CERTAIN TEM - 18
PORARY PROJECTS .— 19
‘‘(i) I N GENERAL .—A building site or 20
construction or installation project, or an 21
installation or drilling rig or ship used for 22
the exploration or exploitation of the sea 23
bed and its subsoil and their natural re- 24
sources, constitutes a permanent establish- 25

23 
HR 33 RFSment only if it lasts, or the activities of the 1
rig or ship lasts, for more than 12 months. 2
‘‘(ii) D ETERMINATION OF 12 -MONTH  3
PERIOD .—For purposes of clause (i), the 4
period over which a building site or con- 5
struction or installation project of a person 6

carry on activities at such building site or 9
construction or installation project but 10

building site or construction or installation 12
project by one or more connected persons. 13
‘‘(C) H ABITUAL EXERCISE OF CONTRACT  14
AUTHORITY TREATED AS PERMANENT ESTAB - 15
LISHMENT .—Notwithstanding subparagraphs 16

Taiwan and has and habitually exercises an au- 21
thority to conclude contracts that are binding 22
on the trade or business, that trade or business 23
shall be deemed to have a permanent establish- 24
ment in the country in which such authority is 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 17, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00023 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H33.RFS H33ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
24 
HR 33 RFSexercised in respect of any activities that the 1

‘‘(D) E XCLUSIONS .— 9
‘‘(i) I N GENERAL .—Notwithstanding 10
subparagraphs (A) and (B), the term ‘per- 11

‘‘(I) the use of facilities solely for 13
the purpose of storage, display, or de- 14

‘‘(II) the maintenance of a stock 17

‘‘(III) the maintenance of a stock 22
of goods or merchandise belonging to 23
the trade or business solely for the 24
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 17, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00024 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H33.RFS H33ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
25 
HR 33 RFSpurpose of processing by another 1
trade or business, 2
‘‘(IV) the maintenance of a fixed 3
place of business solely for the pur- 4
pose of purchasing goods or merchan- 5
dise, or of collecting information, for 6
the trade or business, 7
‘‘(V) the maintenance of a fixed 8
place of business solely for the pur- 9

‘‘(VI) the maintenance of a fixed 13

subclauses (I) through (V), provided 16
that the overall activity of the fixed 17
place of business resulting from this 18

auxiliary character. 20
‘‘(ii) B ROKERS AND OTHER INDE - 21
PENDENT AGENTS .—A trade or business 22

cause it carries on business in such coun- 25

HR 33 RFStry through a broker, general commission 1

‘‘(3) T ESTED GROUP .—The term ‘tested group’ 6

‘‘(A) participates as a member with such 10

‘‘(B) shares losses with such entity pursu- 14
ant to a group relief or other loss sharing re- 15

‘‘(4) C ONNECTED PERSON .—Two persons shall 17
be ‘connected persons’ if one owns, directly or indi- 18
rectly, at least 50 percent of the interests in the 19
other (or, in the case of a corporation, at least 50 20
percent of the aggregate vote and value of the cor- 21
poration’s shares) or another person owns, directly 22
or indirectly, at least 50 percent of the interests (or, 23
in the case of a corporation, at least 50 percent of 24
the aggregate vote and value of the corporation’s 25

27 
HR 33 RFSshares) in each person. In any case, a person shall 1
be connected to another if, based on all the relevant 2
facts and circumstances, one has control of the other 3
or both are under the control of the same person or 4
persons. 5
‘‘(5) F OREIGN COUNTRY OF CONCERN .—The 6

given such term under paragraph (7) of section 8

TITLE II—UNITED STATES-TAI-17

THORIZATION ACT 19
SEC. 201. SHORT TITLE. 20
This title may be cited as the ‘‘United States-Taiwan 21
Tax Agreement Authorization Act’’. 22
SEC. 202. DEFINITIONS. 23
In this title: 24
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:23 Jan 17, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00031 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H33.RFS H33ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS

HR 33 RFS(1) A GREEMENT .—The term ‘‘Agreement’’ 1
means the tax agreement authorized by section 2
203(a). 3
(2) A PPROPRIATE CONGRESSIONAL COMMIT - 4
TEES .—The term ‘‘appropriate congressional com- 5
mittees’’ means— 6
(A) the Committee on Foreign Relations 7
and the Committee on Finance of the Senate; 8
and 9
(B) the Committee on Ways and Means of 10
the House of Representatives. 11
(3) A PPROVAL LEGISLATION .—The term ‘‘ap- 12
proval legislation’’ means legislation that approves 13
the Agreement. 14
(4) I MPLEMENTING LEGISLATION .—The term 15
‘‘implementing legislation’’ means legislation that 16
makes any changes to the Internal Revenue Code of 17
1986 necessary to implement the Agreement. 18
SEC. 203. AUTHORIZATION TO NEGOTIATE AND ENTER 19
INTO AGREEMENT. 20
(a) I NGENERAL .—Subsequent to a determination 21
under section 894A(e)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code 22
of 1986 (as added by the United States-Taiwan Expedited 23
Double-Tax Relief Act), the President is authorized to ne-24
gotiate and enter into a tax agreement relative to Taiwan. 25

CONVENTIONS .—The President shall ensure that— 3

ment conform with provisions customarily con- 5

conventions, as exemplified by the 2016 United 7
States Model Income Tax Convention; and 8
(B) the Agreement does not include ele- 9

States Model Income Tax Convention. 11
(2) I NCORPORATION OF TAX AGREEMENTS AND  12
LAWS .—Notwithstanding paragraph (1), the Agree- 13
ment may incorporate and restate provisions of any 14
agreement, or existing United States law, addressing 15
double taxation for residents of the United States 16
and Taiwan. 17
(3) A UTHORITY .—The Agreement shall include 18
the following statement: ‘‘The Agreement is entered 19
into pursuant to the United States-Taiwan Tax 20
Agreement Authorization Act.’’ 21
(4) E NTRY INTO FORCE .—The Agreement shall 22
include a provision conditioning entry into force 23
upon— 24

commencement of negotiations between the United States 12
and Taiwan on the Agreement at least 15 calendar days 13
before commencing such negotiations. 14

tion. 23
(2) M EETINGS AND OTHER CONSULTATIONS .— 24

SEC. 206. SUBMISSION TO CONGRESS OF AGREEMENT AND 3
IMPLEMENTATION POLICY. 4
(a) S UBMISSION OF AGREEMENT .—Not later than 5
270 days after the President enters into the Agreement, 6
the President or the President’s designee shall submit to 7
Congress— 8
(1) the final text of the Agreement; and 9
(2) a technical explanation of the Agreement. 10
(b) S UBMISSION OF IMPLEMENTATION POLICY .—Not 11
later than 270 days after the President enters into the 12
Agreement, the Secretary of the Treasury shall submit to 13
Congress— 14
(1) a description of those changes to existing 15
laws that the President considers would be required 16
in order to ensure that the United States acts in a 17
manner consistent with the Agreement; and 18
(2) a statement of anticipated administrative 19
action proposed to implement the Agreement. 20

SEC. 209. AUTHORIZATION OF SUBSEQUENT TAX AGREE-6
MENTS RELATIVE TO TAIWAN. 7
(a) I NGENERAL .—Subsequent to the enactment of 8
approval legislation and implementing legislation pursuant 9
to section 207— 10
(1) the term ‘‘tax agreement’’ in section 203(a) 11
shall be treated as including any tax agreement rel- 12
ative to Taiwan which supplements or supersedes 13
the Agreement to which such approval legislation 14
and implementing legislation relates, and 15
(2) the term ‘‘Agreement’’ shall be treated as 16
including such tax agreement. 17
