119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. RES. 8 
Reaffirming the House of Representatives’s commitment to ensuring secure 
elections throughout the United States by recognizing that the presen-tation of valid photograph identification is a fundamental component of secure elections. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona (for himself and Mr. C RANE ) submitted the following 
resolution; which was referred to the Committee on House Administration 
RESOLUTION 
Reaffirming the House of Representatives’s commitment to 
ensuring secure elections throughout the United States by recognizing that the presentation of valid photograph identification is a fundamental component of secure elec-tions. 
Whereas elections allow United States citizens to empower 
their fellow citizens to be their voice in the constitutional republic; 
Whereas the operation of free and fair elections is vital to 
Americans’ trust in government; 
Whereas countries that hold elections without very basic secu-
rity measures eventually lose the support of their people and erode faith in elections and the rule of law; 
VerDate Sep 11 2014 22:17 Jan 04, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6300 E:\BILLS\HR8.IH HR8kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
2 
•HRES 8 IH Whereas absentee voting systems and voting by mail systems 
that lack photograph verification are less secure than in- person voting with photograph verification; 
Whereas United States citizens are required by law to present 
valid photograph identification to prove identity for a wide array of other interactions with government, includ-ing applications for taxpayer-funded food stamps, wel-fare, Social Security, and Medicaid; 
Whereas United States citizens are required by law to present 
valid photograph identification to prove identity for a wide array of interactions with private institutions, in-cluding to open a bank account, rent or buy a house, apply for a mortgage, buy, rent, or operate a motor vehi-cle, board an airplane, get married, purchase firearms, buy a cell phone, apply for fishing and hunting licenses, pick up prescription medication, and many other func-tions; and 
Whereas United States citizens possess no greater commodity 
than the franchise, and understand that protection of the security of voting and elections is crucial for the mainte-nance of the Republic and its way of life: Now, therefore, be it 
Resolved, That the House of Representatives— 1
(1) reaffirms and reiterates its commitment to 2
ensuring secure elections throughout the United 3
States; and 4
(2) recognizes that the presentation of valid 5
photograph identification is a fundamental compo- 6
VerDate Sep 11 2014 22:17 Jan 04, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\HR8.IH HR8kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
3 
•HRES 8 IH nent of secure elections throughout the United 1
States. 2
Æ 
VerDate Sep 11 2014 22:17 Jan 04, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00003 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6301 E:\BILLS\HR8.IH HR8kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB

119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 79 
To nullify certain Executive orders regarding COVID–19 vaccine mandates 
and to prohibit the Secretary of Labor from issuing a rule mandating vaccination against COVID–19, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona (for himself and Mr. C LOUD ) introduced the following 
bill; which was referred to the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, and in addition to the Committees on Education and Workforce, Energy and Commerce, and Ways and Means, for a period to be subse-quently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned 
A BILL 
To nullify certain Executive orders regarding COVID–19 
vaccine mandates and to prohibit the Secretary of Labor from issuing a rule mandating vaccination against COVID–19, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Freedom from Man- 4
dates Act’’. 5
VerDate Sep 11 2014 02:32 Jan 29, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H79.IH H79ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
2 
•HR 79 IHSEC. 2. NULLIFICATION OF CERTAIN EXECUTIVE ORDERS. 1
(a) S AFETY PROTOCOLS FOR FEDERAL CONTRAC - 2
TORS .—Executive Order 14042 (86 Fed. Reg. 50985, re- 3
lating to ensuring adequate COVID–19 safety protocols 4
for Federal contractors) shall have no force or effect. 5
(b) COVID–19 V ACCINE REQUIREMENT .—Executive 6
Order 14043 (86 Fed. Reg. 50989, relating to requiring 7
COVID–19 vaccination for Federal employees) shall have 8
no force or effect. 9
SEC. 3. PROHIBITION OF RULES MANDATING VACCINA-10
TION. 11
The Secretary of Labor may not issue any rule re- 12
quiring employers to mandate vaccination of employees 13
against COVID–19 or requiring testing of employees who 14
are unvaccinated against COVID–19. 15
SEC. 4. PROHIBITION ON MEDICARE AND MEDICAID 16
COVID–19 VACCINATION MANDATES. 17
Notwithstanding any provision of title XI, XVIII, or 18
XIX of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1301 et seq., 19
1395 et seq., 1396 et seq.), the Secretary of Health and 20
Human Services may not require a health care provider, 21
as a condition of participation in the Medicare or Medicaid 22
program, to mandate vaccination of employees against 23
COVID–19 or require testing of employees who are 24
unvaccinated against COVID–19, and may not otherwise 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 02:32 Jan 29, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H79.IH H79ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
3 
•HR 79 IHpenalize such a provider for such provider’s failure to so 1
mandate such vaccination or so require such testing. 2
Æ

119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 72 
To amend title 38, United States Code, to direct the Secretary of Veterans 
Affairs to furnish hyperbaric oxygen therapy to veterans with traumatic brain injury or post-traumatic stress disorder. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona (for himself, Mr. C RANE , and Mr. G OSAR ) introduced 
the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Veterans’ Affairs 
A BILL 
To amend title 38, United States Code, to direct the Sec-
retary of Veterans Affairs to furnish hyperbaric oxygen therapy to veterans with traumatic brain injury or post- traumatic stress disorder. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘TBI and PTSD Treat- 4
ment Act’’. 5
VerDate Sep 11 2014 01:46 Jan 29, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H72.IH H72ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
2 
•HR 72 IHSEC. 2. HYPERBARIC OXYGEN THERAPY FOR VETERANS 1
WITH TRAUMATIC BRAIN INJURY OR POST- 2
TRAUMATIC STRESS DISORDER. 3
(a) I NGENERAL .—Chapter 17 of title 38, United 4
States Code, is amended by inserting after section 1710E 5
the following new section: 6
‘‘§ 1710F. Traumatic brain injury and post-traumatic 7
stress disorder: hyperbaric oxygen ther- 8
apy 9
‘‘(a) A UTHORITY .—The Secretary shall furnish 10
hyperbaric oxygen therapy to a veteran who has a condi-11
tion specified in subsection (b) through a health care pro-12
vider described in section 1703(c)(5) of this title. 13
‘‘(b) C OVERED CONDITIONS .—The conditions speci- 14
fied in this subsection are the following: 15
‘‘(1) Traumatic brain injury. 16
‘‘(2) Post-traumatic stress disorder.’’. 17
(b) C LERICAL AMENDMENT .—The table of sections 18
at the beginning of such chapter is amended by inserting 19
after the item relating to section 1710E the following new 20
item: 21
‘‘1710F. Traumatic brain injury and post-traumatic stress disorder: hyperbaric 
oxygen therapy.’’.

119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 71 
To direct the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to carry out a pilot program 
to improve the ability of veterans to access medical care in medical facilities of the Department of Veterans Affairs and in the community by providing the veterans the ability to choose health care providers. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona (for himself, Mr. C RANE , Mr. W EBSTER of Florida, Ms. 
SALAZAR , Mr. G OSAR , Mrs. L UNA, and Mr. B RECHEEN ) introduced the 
following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Veterans’ Affairs 
A BILL 
To direct the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to carry out 
a pilot program to improve the ability of veterans to access medical care in medical facilities of the Depart-ment of Veterans Affairs and in the community by pro-viding the veterans the ability to choose health care providers. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Veterans Health Care 4
Freedom Act’’. 5
VerDate Sep 11 2014 01:40 Jan 29, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H71.IH H71ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
2 
•HR 71 IHSEC. 2. PILOT PROGRAM ON ABILITY OF VETERANS TO 1
CHOOSE HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS. 2
(a) P ILOT PROGRAM .— 3
(1) R EQUIREMENT .—The Secretary of Veterans 4
Affairs, acting through the Center for Innovation for 5
Care and Payment, shall carry out a pilot program 6
to improve the ability of eligible veterans to access 7
hospital care, medical services, and extended care 8
services through the covered care system by pro- 9
viding the eligible veterans the ability to choose 10
health care providers. 11
(2) L OCATIONS .—The Secretary shall select a 12
minimum of four Veterans Integrated Service Net- 13
works in which to carry out the pilot program under 14
paragraph (1). In making such selection, the Sec- 15
retary shall ensure that the pilot program is carried 16
out in varied geographic areas that include both 17
rural and urban locations. 18
(b) R EMOVAL OF CERTAIN REQUIREMENTS TOAC- 19
CESS CARE.—In carrying out the pilot program under 20
subsection (a), the Secretary shall furnish hospital care, 21
medical services, and extended care services to eligible vet-22
erans through the covered care system as follows: 23
(1) At medical facilities of the Department of 24
Veterans Affairs, regardless of whether the facility is 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 01:40 Jan 29, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H71.IH H71ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
3 
•HR 71 IHin the same Veterans Integrated Service Network as 1
the Network in which the veteran resides. 2
(2) At non-Department facilities pursuant to, 3
as appropriate— 4
(A) section 1703 of title 38, United States 5
Code, without regard to the requirements speci- 6
fied in subsection (d) of such section; or 7
(B) section 1703A of such title, without re- 8
gard to the requirements specified in subsection 9
(a)(1)(C) of such section. 10
(c) E LECTION OF VETERAN .—In accordance with 11
subsections (d) and (e), an eligible veteran participating 12
in the pilot program may elect to receive hospital care, 13
medical services, and extended care services at any pro-14
vider in the covered care system. 15
(d) C OORDINATION OF CARE.— 16
(1) S ELECTION .—Each eligible veteran partici- 17
pating in the pilot program shall select a primary 18
care provider in the covered care system. The pri- 19
mary care provider shall— 20
(A) coordinate with the Secretary and 21
other health care providers the hospital care, 22
medical services, and extended care services fur- 23
nished to the veteran under the pilot program; 24
and 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 01:40 Jan 29, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00003 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H71.IH H71ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
4 
•HR 71 IH(B) refer the veteran to specialty care pro- 1
viders in the covered care system, as clinically 2
necessary. 3
(2) S YSTEMS .—The Secretary shall establish 4
systems as the Secretary determines appropriate to 5
ensure that a primary care provider can effectively 6
coordinate the hospital care, medical services, and 7
extended care services furnished to a veteran under 8
the pilot program. 9
(e) S PECIALTY CARE.— 10
(1) A CCESS .—Subject to subsection (d)(1)(B), 11
an eligible veteran participating in the pilot program 12
may select any specialty care provider in the covered 13
care system from which to receive specialty care. 14
(2) D ESIGNATION .—The Secretary may des- 15
ignate a specialty care provider as a primary care 16
provider of an eligible veteran participating in the 17
pilot program if the Secretary determines that such 18
designation is in the health interests of the veteran 19
(such as an endocrinologist with respect to a veteran 20
diagnosed with diabetes, a neurologist with respect 21
to a veteran diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease, or 22
an obstetrician-gynecologist with respect to a female 23
veteran). 24
VerDate Sep 11 2014 01:40 Jan 29, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00004 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H71.IH H71ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
5 
•HR 71 IH(f) M ENTAL HEALTH CARE.—An eligible veteran 1
participating in the pilot program may select a mental 2
health care provider in the covered care system from which 3
to receive mental health care. 4
(g) I NFORMATION .—In carrying out the pilot pro- 5
gram, the Secretary shall furnish to eligible veterans the 6
information on eligibility, cost sharing, treatments, and 7
providers required for veterans to make informed decisions 8
with respect to— 9
(1) selecting primary care providers and spe- 10
cialty care providers; and 11
(2) treatments available to the veteran. 12
(h) D URATION .— 13
(1) P HASE IN .—The Secretary shall carry out 14
the pilot program during the three-year period be- 15
ginning on the date that is one year after the date 16
of the enactment of this Act. 17

provided by paragraph (5), the Secretary 24
shall’’; and 25

•HR 71 IH(1) I MPLEMENTATION .—On a quarterly basis 1
during the two-year period beginning on the date of 2
the enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall submit 3
to the Committees on Veterans’ Affairs of the House 4
of Representatives and the Senate a report on the 5

port shall contain a description of the final design 7
of the pilot program. 8

the date of the submission of the final report under 11
paragraph (1) and ending on the date of the conclu- 12
sion of the pilot program, the Secretary shall submit 13
to the Committees on Veterans’ Affairs of the House 14
of Representatives and the Senate a report on the 15
results of the pilot program. 16

with the Committees on Veterans’ Affairs of the House 18
of Representatives and the Senate, may prescribe regula-19
tions to carry out this section. 20
(k) N OADDITIONAL APPROPRIATIONS .—No addi- 21
tional funds are authorized to be appropriated to carry 22
out this section, and this section shall be carried out using 23
amounts otherwise made available to the Veterans Health 24
Administration. 25

•HR 71 IH(l) D EFINITIONS .—In this section: 1
(1) The term ‘‘covered care system’’ means 2
each— 3
(A) medical facility of the Department; 4
(B) health care provider specified in sub- 5
section 1703(c) of title 38, United States Code; 6
and 7
(C) eligible entity or provider that has en- 8
tered into a Veterans Care Agreement under 9
section 1703A of such title. 10
(2) The term ‘‘eligible veteran’’ means a vet- 11
eran who is enrolled in the patient enrollment sys- 12
tem of the Department of Veterans Affairs under 13
section 1705 of title 38, United States Code. 14
(3) The term ‘‘non-Department facility’’ has 15
the meaning given that term in section 1701 of title 16
38, United States Code. 17

119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 110 
To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to expand the deduction 
for qualified business income, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on Ways and Means 
A BILL 
To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to expand 
the deduction for qualified business income, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Small Business Pros- 4
perity Act of 2025’’. 5
SEC. 2. INCREASE AND EXPANSION OF DEDUCTION FOR 6
QUALIFIED BUSINESS INCOME. 7
(a) D EDUCTION MADE PERMANENT .—Section 199A 8
of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by strik-9
ing subsection (i). 10
VerDate Sep 11 2014 05:17 Jan 29, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H110.IH H110kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
2 
•HR 110 IH(b) D EDUCTION TOACHIEVE A TOPRATE ON  1

sections (a)(2) and (b)(1)(B) of section 199A of such Code 3
are each amended by striking ‘‘20 percent’’ and inserting 4
‘‘43 percent (47 percent in the case of any taxable year 5
beginning after December 31, 2025)’’. 6
(c) R EPEAL OF LIMITATION BASED ON W–2 W AGES  7
PAIDWITHRESPECT TO THE TRADE OR BUSINESS , TOP 8
RATE ON QUALIFIED BUSINESS INCOME .—Section 9
199A(b)(2) of such Code is amended to read as follows: 10
‘‘(2) D ETERMINATION OF DEDUCTIBLE  11
AMOUNT FOR EACH TRADE OR BUSINESS .—The 12
amount determined under this paragraph with re- 13
spect to any qualified trade or business is 43 percent 14
(47 percent in the case of any taxable year begin- 15
ning after December 31, 2025) of the taxpayer’s 16
qualified business income with respect to the quali- 17
fied trade or business.’’. 18
(d) R EPEAL OF EXCLUSION OF SPECIFIED SERVICE  19
TRADES OR BUSINESSES .—Section 199A(d) of such Code 20
is amended to read as follows: 21
‘‘(d) Q UALIFIED TRADE OR BUSINESS .—For pur- 22
poses of this section, the term ‘qualified trade or business’ 23
means any trade or business other than the trade or busi-24
ness of performing services as an employee.’’. 25

•HR 110 IHSEC. 3. NO TAXABLE EVENT FOR CHANGE OF CORPORATE 1
FORM. 2
Notwithstanding any provision of the Internal Rev- 3
enue Code of 1986, a change in the organizational struc-4
ture of a corporation, however organized, into another or-5
ganizational structure is not a taxable event for the pur-6
poses of such Code if there is no change among the own-7
ers, their ownership interests, or the assets of the organi-8
zation (other than a de minimis change in such assets). 9
The preceding sentence shall apply to changes in organiza-10
tional structure occurring after December 31, 2024. 11
SEC. 4. REPEAL OF ESTATE TAX AND RETENTION OF BASIS 12
STEP-UP. 13
Effective for estates of decedents dying after Decem- 14
ber 31, 2024, chapter 11 of the Internal Revenue Code 15
of 1986 is repealed. 16

119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 27 
To amend the Controlled Substances Act with respect to the scheduling 
of fentanyl-related substances, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. G RIFFITH (for himself, Mr. L ATTA , Mr. G UTHRIE , Mr. B ILIRAKIS , Mr. 
HUDSON , Mr. C ARTER of Georgia, Mr. P ALMER , Mr. D UNN of Florida, 
Mr. C RENSHAW , Mr. J OYCE of Pennsylvania, Mr. P FLUGER , Mrs. 
HARSHBARGER , Mrs. C AMMACK , Mrs. M ILLER -MEEKS , Mr. W OMACK , 
Mr. B UCHANAN , Mrs. M ILLER of West Virginia, Mr. M OOLENAAR , Mr. 
BOST, Mr. E VANS of Colorado, Mr. F ITZGERALD , Mr. L ANGWORTHY , Mr. 
CLINE , Mr. M EUSER , Mr. V ANDREW, Mr. F EENSTRA , and Mr. N UNN 
of Iowa) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Com-mittee on Energy and Commerce, and in addition to the Committee on the Judiciary, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the juris-diction of the committee concerned 
A BILL 
To amend the Controlled Substances Act with respect to 
the scheduling of fentanyl-related substances, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Halt All Lethal Traf- 4
ficking of Fentanyl Act’’ or the ‘‘HALT Fentanyl Act’’. 5
VerDate Sep 11 2014 20:28 Jan 27, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H27.IH H27kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
2 
•HR 27 IHSEC. 2. CLASS SCHEDULING OF FENTANYL-RELATED SUB-1
STANCES. 2
Section 202(c) of the Controlled Substances Act (21 3
U.S.C. 812(c)) is amended by adding at the end of sched-4
ule I the following: 5
‘‘(e)(1) Unless specifically exempted or unless listed 6
in another schedule, any material, compound, mixture, or 7
preparation which contains any quantity of a fentanyl-re-8
lated substance, or which contains the salts, isomers, and 9
salts of isomers of a fentanyl-related substance whenever 10
the existence of such salts, isomers, and salts of isomers 11
is possible within the specific chemical designation. 12
‘‘(2) For purposes of paragraph (1), except as 13
provided in paragraph (3), the term ‘fentanyl-related 14
substance’ means any substance that is structurally 15
related to fentanyl by 1 or more of the following 16
modifications: 17
‘‘(A) By replacement of the phenyl portion 18
of the phenethyl group by any monocycle, 19
whether or not further substituted in or on the 20
monocycle. 21
‘‘(B) By substitution in or on the 22
phenethyl group with alkyl, alkenyl, alkoxyl, 23
hydroxyl, halo, haloalkyl, amino, or nitro 24
groups. 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 20:28 Jan 27, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H27.IH H27kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
3 
•HR 27 IH‘‘(C) By substitution in or on the piper- 1
idine ring with alkyl, alkenyl, alkoxyl, ester, 2
ether, hydroxyl, halo, haloalkyl, amino, or nitro 3
groups. 4
‘‘(D) By replacement of the aniline ring 5
with any aromatic monocycle whether or not 6
further substituted in or on the aromatic mono- 7
cycle. 8
‘‘(E) By replacement of the N–propionyl 9
group with another acyl group. 10
‘‘(3) A substance that satisfies the definition of 11
the term ‘fentanyl-related substance’ in paragraph 12
(2) shall nonetheless not be treated as a fentanyl-re- 13
lated substance subject to this schedule if the sub- 14
stance— 15
‘‘(A) is controlled by action of the Attorney 16
General under section 201; or 17
‘‘(B) is otherwise expressly listed in a 18
schedule other than this schedule. 19
‘‘(4)(A) The Attorney General may by order 20
publish in the Federal Register a list of substances 21
that satisfy the definition of the term ‘fentanyl-re- 22
lated substance’ in paragraph (2). 23
‘‘(B) The absence of a substance from a 24
list published under subparagraph (A) does not 25

4 
•HR 27 IHnegate the control status of the substance 1
under this schedule if the substance satisfies 2
the definition of the term ‘fentanyl-related sub- 3
stance’ in paragraph (2).’’. 4

SEC. 5. RULEMAKING. 10
(a) I NTERIM FINAL RULES .—The Attorney Gen- 11
eral— 12
(1) shall, not later than 6 months after the date 13
of enactment of this Act, issue rules to implement 14
this Act and the amendments made by this Act; and 15
(2) may issue the rules under paragraph (1) as 16
interim final rules. 17
(b) P ROCEDURE FOR FINAL RULE.— 18
(1) E FFECTIVENESS OF INTERIM FINAL  19
RULES .—A rule issued by the Attorney General as 20
an interim final rule under subsection (a) shall be- 21
come immediately effective as an interim final rule 22
without requiring the Attorney General to dem- 23
onstrate good cause therefor, notwithstanding sub- 24
VerDate Sep 11 2014 20:28 Jan 27, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00021 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H27.IH H27kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
22 
•HR 27 IHparagraph (B) of section 553(b) of title 5, United 1
States Code. 2
(2) O PPORTUNITY FOR COMMENT AND HEAR - 3
ING.—An interim final rule issued under subsection 4
(a) shall give interested persons the opportunity to 5
comment and to request a hearing. 6
(3) F INAL RULE .—After the conclusion of such 7
proceedings, the Attorney General shall issue a final 8
rule to implement this Act and the amendments 9
made by this Act in accordance with section 553 of 10
title 5, United States Code. 11

fentanyl-related substance’’ after ‘‘any analogue of 17

propanamide’’; and 19

propanamide’’. 23

SEC. 7. APPLICABILITY; OTHER MATTERS. 12
(a) I NGENERAL .—Irrespective of the date on which 13
the rules required by section 4 are finalized, the amend-14
ments made by this Act apply beginning as of the enact-15
ment of this Act. 16
(b) R ULE OF CONSTRUCTION .—Nothing in the 17
amendments made by this Act may be construed as evi-18
dence that, in applying sections 401(b)(1) and 1010(b) of 19
the Controlled Substances Act (21 U.S.C. 841(b)(1) and 20
960(b)) with respect to conduct occurring before the date 21
of the enactment of this Act, a fentanyl-related substance 22
(as defined by such amendments) is not an analogue of 23
N-phenyl-N-[1-(2-phenylethyl)-4-piperidinyl] 24
propanamide. 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 20:28 Jan 27, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00023 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H27.IH H27kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
24 
•HR 27 IH(c) S ENSE OF CONGRESS .—The Congress agrees with 1
the interpretation of the Controlled Substances Act (21 2
U.S.C. 801 et seq.) in United States v. McCray, 346 F. 3
Supp. 3d 363 (2018). 4

119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 26 
To prohibit a moratorium on the use of hydraulic fracturing. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. P FLUGER introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Com-
mittee on Natural Resources, and in addition to the Committee on En-ergy and Commerce, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned 
A BILL 
To prohibit a moratorium on the use of hydraulic fracturing. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Protecting American 4
Energy Production Act’’. 5
SEC. 2. PROTECTING AMERICAN ENERGY PRODUCTION. 6
(a) S ENSE OF CONGRESS .—It is the sense of Con- 7
gress that States should maintain primacy for the regula-8
tion of hydraulic fracturing for oil and natural gas produc-9
tion on State and private lands. 10
VerDate Sep 11 2014 05:19 Jan 28, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H26.IH H26kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
2 
•HR 26 IH(b) P ROHIBITION ON DECLARATION OF A MORATO - 1
RIUM ON HYDRAULIC FRACTURING .—Notwithstanding 2
any other provision of law, the President may not declare 3
a moratorium on the use of hydraulic fracturing unless 4
such moratorium is authorized by an Act of Congress. 5

119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 35 
To impose criminal and immigration penalties for intentionally fleeing a 
pursuing Federal officer while operating a motor vehicle. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. C ISCOMANI (for himself, Ms. D ELACRUZ, Mr. H IGGINS of Louisiana, 
Mr. W EBER of Texas, Mr. S TAUBER , Mr. F ITZGERALD , Mrs. H OUCHIN , 
Mr. M EUSER , Mr. T ONY GONZALES of Texas, Ms. T ENNEY , Mr. 
GIMENEZ , Mr. F EENSTRA , Mr. E LLZEY , Mr. V ALADAO , Mr. K USTOFF , 
Mrs. M ILLER -MEEKS , Mr. N UNN of Iowa, Mr. S COTT FRANKLIN of Flor-
ida, Mr. B UCHANAN , and Mrs. C AMMACK ) introduced the following bill; 
which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary 
A BILL 
To impose criminal and immigration penalties for inten-
tionally fleeing a pursuing Federal officer while operating a motor vehicle. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as ‘‘Agent Raul Gonzalez Offi- 4
cer Safety Act’’. 5
VerDate Sep 11 2014 05:20 Jan 28, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H35.IH H35kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
2 
•HR 35 IHSEC. 2. CRIMINAL PENALTIES FOR EVADING ARREST OR 1
DETENTION. 2
(a) I NGENERAL .—Chapter 2 of title 18, United 3
States Code, is amended by adding at the end the fol-4
lowing: 5
‘‘§ 40B. Evading arrest or detention while operating a 6
motor vehicle 7
‘‘(a) O FFENSE .—A person commits an offense under 8
this section by operating a motor vehicle within 100 miles 9
of the United States border while intentionally fleeing 10
from— 11
‘‘(1) a pursuing U.S. Border Patrol agent act- 12
ing pursuant to lawful authority; or 13
‘‘(2) any pursuing Federal, State, or local law 14
enforcement officer who is actively assisting, or 15
under the command of, U.S. Border Patrol. 16
‘‘(b) P ENALTIES .— 17
‘‘(1) I N GENERAL .—Except as provided in para- 18
graphs (2) and (3), any person who commits an of- 19
fense described in subsection (a) shall be— 20
‘‘(A) imprisoned for a term of not more 21
than 2 years; 22
‘‘(B) fined under this title; or 23
‘‘(C) subject to the penalties described in 24
subparagraphs (A) and (B). 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 05:20 Jan 28, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H35.IH H35kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
3 
•HR 35 IH‘‘(2) S ERIOUS BODILY INJURY .—If serious bod- 1
ily injury results from the commission of an offense 2
described in subsection (a), the person committing 3
such offense shall be— 4
‘‘(A) imprisoned for a term of not less 5
than 5 years and not more than 20 years; 6
‘‘(B) fined under this title; or 7
‘‘(C) subject to the penalties described in 8
subparagraphs (A) and (B). 9
‘‘(3) D EATH .—If the death of any person re- 10
sults from the commission of an offense described in 11
subsection (a), the person committing such offense 12
shall be— 13
‘‘(A) imprisoned for a term of not less 14
than 10 years and up to life; 15
‘‘(B) fined under this title; or 16
‘‘(C) subject to the penalties described in 17
subparagraphs (A) and (B).’’. 18
(b) C LERICAL AMENDMENT .—The analysis for chap- 19
ter 2 of title 18, United States Code, is amended by add-20
ing at the end the following: 21
‘‘40B. Evading arrest or detention while operating a motor vehicle.’’.

•HR 35 IHSEC. 3. INADMISSIBILITY, DEPORTABILITY, AND INELIGI-1
BILITY RELATED TO EVADING ARREST OR 2
DETENTION WHILE OPERATING A MOTOR VE- 3
HICLE. 4
(a) I NADMISSIBILITY .—Section 212(a)(2) of the Im- 5
migration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1182(a)(2)) is 6
amended by adding at the end the following: 7
‘‘(J) E VADING ARREST OR DETENTION  8
WHILE OPERATING A MOTOR VEHICLE .—Any 9
alien who has been convicted of, who admits 10
having committed, or who admits committing 11
acts which constitute the essential elements of 12
a violation of section 40B(a) of title 18, United 13
States Code, is inadmissible.’’. 14
(b) D EPORTABILITY .—Section 237(a)(2) of the Im- 15
migration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1227(a)(2)) is 16
amended by adding at the end the following: 17
‘‘(G) E VADING ARREST OR DETENTION  18
WHILE OPERATING A MOTOR VEHICLE .—Any 19
alien who has been convicted of, who admits 20
having committed, or who admits committing 21
acts which constitute the essential elements of 22
a violation of section 40B(a) of title 18, United 23
States Code, is deportable.’’. 24

•HR 35 IH(c) I NELIGIBILITY FOR RELIEF .—Chapter 2 of title 1
II of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended by 2
inserting after section 208 the following: 3
‘‘SEC. 208A. INELIGIBILITY FOR RELIEF RELATED TO EVAD-4
ING ARREST OR DETENTION WHILE OPER- 5
ATING A MOTOR VEHICLE. 6
‘‘Any alien who has been convicted of, who admits 7
having committed, or who admits committing acts which 8
constitute the essential elements of a violation of section 9
40B(a) of title 18, United States Code, shall be ineligible 10
for relief under the immigration laws, including asylum 11
under section 208.’’. 12
SEC. 4. ANNUAL REPORT. 13
The Attorney General, in conjunction with the Sec- 14
retary of Homeland Security, shall submit an annual re-15
port to the Committee on the Judiciary of the Senate and 16
the Committee on the Judiciary of the House of Rep-17
resentatives that— 18
(1) identifies the number of people who com- 19
mitted a violation of section 40B(a) of title 18, 20
United States Code, as added by section 2(a); and 21
(2) summarizes— 22
(A) the number of individuals who were 23
charged with the violation referred to in para- 24
graph (1); 25

•HR 35 IH(B) the number of individuals who were 1
apprehended but not charged with such viola- 2

(C) the number of individuals who com- 4
mitted such violation but were not apprehended; 5
(D) the penalties sought in the charging 6
documents pertaining to such violation; and 7
(E) the penalties imposed for such viola- 8
tion. 9

119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 34 
To deposit portions of revenue generated from public lands into the Social 
Security Trust Fund. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. G OSAR introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee 
on Natural Resources, and in addition to the Committee on Agriculture, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned 
A BILL 
To deposit portions of revenue generated from public lands 
into the Social Security Trust Fund. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Land And Social Secu- 4
rity Optimization Act’’ or ‘‘LASSO Act’’. 5
SEC. 2. PUBLIC LAND REVENUE FOR SOCIAL SECURITY 6
TRUST FUND. 7
(a) I NGENERAL .—Notwithstanding any other law, 8
each fiscal year, 10 percent of amounts collected by the 9
VerDate Sep 11 2014 05:20 Jan 28, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H34.IH H34kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
2 
•HR 34 IHDepartment of the Interior and the Department of Agri-1
culture from the revenue generated by covered public 2
lands during the preceding fiscal year shall be deposited 3
into the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund estab-4
lished under section 201(a) of the Social Security Act (42 5
U.S.C. 401(a)). 6
(b) R ULES OF CONSTRUCTION .—Nothing in this Act 7
shall be construed as— 8
(1) authorizing the Secretary of the Interior or 9
the Secretary of Agriculture to raise the price of any 10
of the activities through which revenue is generated 11
on covered public lands; or 12
(2) reducing amounts made available to States, 13
Indian Tribes, territories, or local governments from 14
revenue generated by covered public lands. 15
(c) C OVERED PUBLIC LANDS DEFINED .—In this 16
Act, the term ‘‘covered public lands’’ means any land 17
under the administrative jurisdiction— 18
(1) of the Department of the Interior, including 19
submerged lands on the Outer Continental Shelf (as 20
such term is defined in section 2 of the Outer Conti- 21
nental Shelf Lands Act (43 U.S.C. 1331); or 22
(2) the Forest Service. 23
